149876517.review:
[i]The Tiny Bang Story[/i] is very similar to [url=steamcommunity.com/id/atisz2/recommended/855640/]My Brother Rabbit[/url] in the aspect of having hidden objects in it, yet without being a hidden object game entirely (there are no separate screens with listed items we have to find) and in that it was primarily made for children, marked by having no spoken or written dialogues or text whatsoever. The game is a totally relaxing experience and there's no better word to describe it, than cute. Unlike the previously mentioned title, It comes without a touching story however, that is so insignificant, that we get a clearer description about what happened from the game's store page, rather than from the super short intro.

A meteor explodes near TIny Planet (yes, that's its name) which makes the puzzle pieces the planet consists of (?) to scatter. Our main objective is to find these pieces and put them back to where they belong - onto the planet... [strike]to make it whole again (no, it has nothing to do with [i]Dead Space[/i] :D)[/strike] and that's it.

So with a barely tangible plot, what we get is a journey with a wide variety of puzzles, hidden object search and various minigames throughout the 5 chapters the game has to offer. The jigsaw puzzle pieces are usually lazily hidden behind an object, however in order to progress and to be able to step forward to the next screen we usually have to solve one of the mentioned minigames. The counter in the upper left section of the screen not only shows us how many more we need to find, but also indicates the number of the occasional extra collectibles (like a set number of handles for example). We can - and we must - enter buildings as they also contain items we need. The items we can assemble from these pieces are the key to acess new areas.
When we collected all the necessary items, we often have to push a conspicuously placed button, to set things in motion and be able to proceed.
Between chapters, we get back to the planet from the main menu screen, where we have to put the unlocked puzzle pieces back manually, so we can move and continue playing there.
The difficulty of the minigames is fair which doesn't break the relaxing nature of the game, although the one with the orbs in the rotating annuluses, where they have to be aligned by colour, may be (it is, even for adults) too difficult for children.
There are no bugs, but interaction with certain objects can be unresponsive and we may have to click multiple times on some of them.
Clicking on the little flies on the screen and collecting enough of them (new ones appear as time passes) will provide us a direction towards missing items if we get stuck, which would be a nice touch, but it sometimes points at already done tasks.

Pastel colours dominate the cute graphics, with unique, partially mechanical looking structures made of household items and hand-drawn - often not really matching - characters (there's a very realistic old man, then a rather stylized looking kid from a family portrait for example, who, with a slight exaggeration, could get casted to a horror movie), but since there's basically no story, there's nothing that links these people together or make them relevant, making them hardly more than just stage sets.
Unfortunately the game runs in a 1024x768 resolution, but the worst thing is that due to the 4:3 aspect ratio, everything looks distorted on [strike]modern[/strike] all screens, which is strange considering in 2011, when the game was released, 16:9 displays were already pretty common.
The background tunes are lovely and they manage to represent the slight distinctiveness between the chapters (even though the xylophone seems to play a large role in all of them) rather than the graphic design, they are rather short however and thus loop a lot. 

[i]The Tiny Bang Story[/i] is a cute little puzzle/hidden object game, that lacks a bit of additional polish and without a plot that would make its world memorable or close to us. It's stil a good game however due to the quality of its minigames and its relaxing nature.

PROS
+ a large variety of puzzles and minigames
+ colourful graphics
+ fitting, relaxing music
+ creative hint system

CONS
- no plot, characters are just decorations
- the hints don't always point to the right direction
- we may have to click on some objects multiple times

RATING
6/10

[i]The Tiny Bang Story[/i] was free to claim on September 24, 2018 to celebrate the release of the developers' new game, [url=store.steampowered.com/app/351100/Niffelheim/]Niffelheim[/url].

148869471.review:
The Tiny Bang Story is an enchanting and visually stunning point-and-click adventure game set in a whimsical world filled with beautiful hand-drawn illustrations. 

The game begins in the aftermath of a cosmic disaster, in which you’ll have to restore a fragmented world and its inhabitants. As you explore each of the five distinct chapters, you'll encounter intricate puzzles, mini-games, and a number of hidden objects that need to be found and pieced together. These challenges are elegantly woven into the game's narrative, creating a seamless and immersive experience.

One of The Tiny Bang Story's outstanding features is its artistic presentation. The hand-drawn graphics are breathtaking and the attention to detail in every scene makes the game feel like a work of art in motion. The great soundtrack further enhances the experience, creating a tranquil atmosphere that is both soothing and contemplative.

The game's puzzles are diverse and well-designed, offering a range of difficulties that cater to players with varying skill levels. While some puzzles are straightforward and easy, others can be more complex and require careful observation and problem-solving. This balanced mix ensures that the game remains engaging without becoming overly frustrating.

However, it's worth noting that the game's narrative is minimal, primarily conveyed through its visuals rather than through dialogue or text. This allows for a more universal gaming experience, as language barriers are less of an issue. On the other hand, if you're looking for a rich narrative-driven game, The Tiny Bang Story might feel somewhat lacking in that department.

In summary, The Tiny Bang Story is a delightful and captivating adventure that will appeal to fans of point-and-click puzzle games and hidden object challenges. Its serene atmosphere and stunning visuals create a memorable gaming experience that invites players to embark on a journey through a beautifully broken world.

139587878.review:
This game was sitting into my library since ages, it is one of those give away games that still drop cards, as later Steam negated this option to any other "get now for free and keep it forever" game.  And I had to reach the point that I was done with anything else I was playing AND unwilling to start something new.  Then I thought that this one would have been the right game to play, where I wouldn't be tasked with a steep learning curve, nor fast paced game play, nor the need to plan, calculate, list anything, and it delivered all of these : )

Game play wise it is really relaxing and linear, BGM and sound effects are nice and never intrusive, puzzles are nothing too much complicated, searching around for hidden objects is fun and it last exactly that much it has to last (before to become repetitive then annoying).  It should take in between 3 and 4 hours in total, or even less if trying to speed run it (not advised anyway) : )

On the negative side there is an issue with full screen mode, reported often by many users as I saw in the forum, because I got victim of it me too.  In my case game can run in full screen mode but after the first two areas and about two hours spent, it started to crash at next launch.  After searching enough and trying enough, my best option was to rename the game folder with save and start it over, in windowed mode.

Unfortunately settings are baked into the save itself, and it is encoded.  If it were a simple settings.txt file where to manually remove full screen mode, it would have been much easier to fix this issue, anyway didn't take too much time to be back at the same point and carry on.  If any, for anyone going to play it, set full screen mode immediately then quit and try to launch it again.  If it succeed fine, otherwise delete the folder and start over in windowed mode.  Folder is ...\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\Colibri Games\The Tiny Bang Story for instance, otherwise try any other advanced solution suggested in the forum.

And once game is complete, player can tackle again [i]most[/i] puzzles in a special room, but I guess that to play it over is much better (after a long while of course).  Strongly suggested if in the right mood ; )

Good HOG game, short and sweet. Art style is nice, reminiscent of games by Amanita Design. Great music too. Well worth the price IMO.

There are some negatives though. They weren't enough to sour my experience, but YMMV:
[list]
[*]Story is non-existent with no indication of your motivation, or even who you are.
[*]The hint system is annoying, and doesn't help you if the thing you need is behind an interaction (eg. opening a pot). Also, the hints tend to give the solution away, when what you really want is just a clue.
[*]Some of the puzzles felt out of place (the boat and plane ones), requiring quick responses and mouse positioning in a game where you normally play at your own pace. I'm a diverse gamer so they were more frustrating than hard for me, but they might be too challenging for people who mainly play HOGs.
[/list]
IMPORTANT: If you have a custom scaling in your Display Options, change it back to 100%, otherwise your cursor won't be visible in full screen.

129908139.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

108240079.review:
A brain-aching concoction of point-and-click puzzle and hidden-object genres, [i]The Tiny Bang Story[/i] invites you to save its post-apocalypse surreal world with clickity-clickety-clicks, clicks, clicks, and clicks (I have to admit that in the late game I just went clicking like mad, no brain).  

You will be asked to find designated objects strewn all over the places and, upon having found them all, the puzzle minigame will be unlocked. I love that hidden-object aspect of the game, but the puzzles were quite... various and enjoyable. Okay. But there are some puzzles which you probably won't know what to do with it actually. Many you can experiment and will finally figure it out. But what if you can't? And since this game suffers the serious lack of clue (and we players, with it), you will be forced to resort to view the puzzle solution. And with no explanation whatsoever still. Also, there was this specific one in which the game control was the worst I did wonder how they could release the game without fixing it, and not even an update to solve the issue. And that [i]color-coded world map puzzle[/i]. Vexed and bordering on despair, yet too obstinate to yield and view the solution, I just randomly clicked it until it solved itself. Pretty funny when you put it that way. But, yeah, some puzzles were simply too much and did offset all the fun, the amount of which was not that great in the first place.

108111637.review: A quick point and find. Good buy at a sale price. Puzzles are generally not explained as the game lacks any kind of written language, but easy enough to grasp with no time. I want to like this game. i actually remember playing a demo of it a long time ago and enjoying it, but the full version falls flat.

My main complaints are:
1) The size of the game window. It's super small for a hidden object game. If you try to put the game into fullscreen mode, there's a good chance your cursor will disappear. I ended up having to use Magnifier just to play the game.
2) Some of the puzzles are a bit too long. No one wants to play Simon Says 10 times in a row.
3) Hint button is mostly useless. I got stuck in Chapter 2 and tried the hint, but it wouldn't show me what I needed to do. I ended up having to look at the walkthrough to find out I hadn't opened a window because the hint would not give me any indication of where the last ball was.
4) No minigame skip. Some of the minigames are next to impossible to complete and there's no way to skip them. You just have to sit there and try and try and try until you either win or quit the game.

SInce the game doesn't have any Steam achievements and I spent less than a dollar on this game... I'm going too give up and uninstall it. I won't even bother with a refund.

106263793.review:
While I did enjoy parts of the game and don't feel ripped off since I only spent $1 or less on it, I still can't recommend it. It's a cheap imitation of an Amanita game, reminding me of Samorost, and Machinarium in particular with the pixel hunting, completely out of place action minigames and at least one puzzle that made me want to kick the developer's dog. Unfortunately, unlike Samorost or Machinarium, there's no story or likeable characters, and the "difficulty" spikes too often.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Bright, colorful artwork.

+Very relaxing music. You'll have to Google a download for it since the original free posting of music is now a dead link.

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Between 3-5 hours of play, depending on how often you look at a guide because you're tired of the game's bullcrap.

~4:3 aspect ratio and small resolution. Not a big deal at all, but it'll make someone whinge, I'm sure.

~There is a hint system for finding objects, but it requires clicking on a large number of ever-present dragonflies to "charge up". It's baffling design and isn't any help with puzzles.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-45 seconds to load a glorified DOS game into a usable menu? I can boot all of 2016's Doom faster - and that's got half a dozen unskippable opening splash screens!

-Moments of extreme pixel hunting; not just to find an object, but to successfully click on it.

-The puzzle items on the right side of the screen can block the game environment

-Puzzle pieces are bugged or pointless. You can complete levels without enough, and in one case, too many somehow.

-No ability to skip puzzles and you're going to want to pass on a few due to lacking feedback, or their being a choice between a ton of trial and error or major brainstorming that doesn't fit how casual the rest of the game is.

-No ability to skip that second stupid Colibrivision minigame. Tiger handheld games weren't fun for this crap in the 80's and they're not fun now in an otherwise ostensibly casual puzzle game. Machinarium tried this years prior and got flamed for it...why would you imitate the second worst part of that game?

-Can't exit from the intermission jigsaw puzzle sections until completed, and half the pieces are nondescript blue sky.

One of the first things you will notice about this game is the unbelievable graphics.

105102784.review:
I played this with my kids, aged 7 and 5, and it was lovely.

It's basically a hidden object game.  There's little in the way of story, it's just a collection of puzzles and a jigsaw minigame.  Saying that, though, reduces it too far.  The gentle music, the lovely artwork and charming depictions of the people and puzzles all combine together to make a lovely, relaxing little game.

In general, the 5yo enjoyed looking for all the puzzle pieces, which are cunningly hidden like "where's wally" in the artwork.  The 7yo enjoyed trying to solve the puzzles themselves, while daddy (47yo) was there to explain what some things were, and try to keep the other two guided to look in the right places.

The game took about 10 hours to play, but generally because I left the kids to it.  The puzzles are usually not too hard, although there are a few that need quite a bit of puzzling through.  The hidden-object part of the game is usually not too bad, but there are some items which are hidden in very hard-to-see places unless you have a really good monitor.  We tried to play it on the TV through Steamlink, and you needed to get right up to the TV to see some things  occasionally.

We really loved this game, and my 5yo keeps asking if we can play it again from scratch :)

THEN!!!! there is 1 missing and you have practically scoured all the map to try find it. NO HELP BUTTON FOR THAT.
Sooo, in the interest of giving the game the benefit of my doubt, i continued on another puzzle i came across which again had no rules, so "friggin figure it out yerself mate!" says the fakin game.
I do and it goes through another pointless map search to input a 'secret code' and LO-AND-BEHOLD the last missing piece of that original problem. You would think that HEY, now you should be happy right???!

101455961.review: This was such a delight to play. Almost 5 hours of gameplay later and my brain feels frazzled and satisfied simultaneously. The graphics were so gorgeous and quaint. But my favourite aspect had to be the musical score that played during the main puzzle screen. It honestly took me back to Barbie Fairytopia for some odd reason, but I absolutely adored it. The concept of completing a puzzle to reach a new level was unique, and the various puzzles within each level gave substance to the game that I had not been expecting. I wish there was more because I had so much fun playing. This is yet another great game for people who enjoy multiple challenges (sorta like Where's Wally/Waldo and puzzles) without the pressure of a timer.  My only critique was that I wish there had been more of a tutorial on how to play in the beginning because I was incredibly confused at first. (Maybe I didn't read certain information on the Store Page...or my brain was a little slow today) Besides this, I managed to catch on with a little help from the interwebs and I was on my way. Moral of the story: You've simply got to give this game a go!

There are also two arcade type games that won't be a problem for most people but I'm terrible at that stuff. Just guiding a boat or spaceship through a maze and avoiding incoming hazards. I was very frustrated starting this game. There was no indication that I was moving towards a main menu, and my game was loaded in a very small resolution. I couldn't get it to stretch properly to full screen on any of my monitors. Not just with black bars on the side, it wasn't working properly.

I had to delete the files here first: C:\Users\*YourUserName*\AppData\Roaming\Colibri Games\The Tiny Bang Story\

That fixed the issue with not properly stretching to fullscreen. But I still had no mouse. Had to go to the .exe, run in compatability mode for windows 7, disable full screen optimization, run as administrator, then under change high DPI settings, at the bottom, change from application to system in the drop down for override high DPI scaling behavior. Overriding high DPI scaling behavior had to be redone every time I turned my computer on. What a pain just to get a game working. 

However, all of that being said, once I got the game up and running. It was quite enjoyable. It felt like part simple puzzle game and part hidden object game. The concept was very simple, but I definitely enjoyed it.

One puzzle just didn't make sense and I had to google it because it didn't seem to be working despite me knowing how to solve it. The solutions I found lined up with what I was doing, so I started the puzzle over again and it worked. But I spent five mins literally spinning with no luck. A few of the other puzzles I didn't particularly care for. But overall, it was quite fun. I had no idea what the tiny bang story was though lol.

It's only a few bucks, so if it's ever one sale, it's a no brainer to pick up. But even at full price it's worth five bucks.

Tiny Bang Story is a beautifully illustrated point-and-click hidden object game with a chill soundtrack and relaxing atmosphere.

94903897.review:
[b][i]I Really Tried To Like It: 5/10[/i][/b]
-----------------
Tiny Bang Story has some good concepts but has some serious drawbacks that prevents it from being an enjoyable game. No clear direction, poor hit detection, tedious gameplay and sections where the game menu is removed,  amount to a frustrating hour that may make you wish you were at work rather than at play.
-----------------
[b]What They Got Right[/b]
-----------------
Tiny Bang is an [u]amalgamation of various Point & Click games[/u] that rather gel well together; Hidden Items, Matching Puzzle, Jigsaw. There's even a section where you play a mini first person shooter game (balloon section in stage 1). You wouldn't think that these things go together but Colibri Games made it work... sort of. 
----------------
[b]What They Got Wrong[/b]
----------------
You're not told how the game works, you're suppose to figure it out yourself. That's fine in a platformer game where you have the benefit of trial and error, but when you're a hidden items game and you have [u]no clear indication[/u] of what to do with items you collected, you're will get lost within the first 15 minutes. 

Other puzzle games have a clear logic to it - that is, if you do A, it results in B - this game somehow unsuccessfully communicate what the rules are and how it should be played. 

[u]This wouldn't be so bad if the control schemes were tight.[/u] As it is, trying to snap pieces into place requires some weird precision for a point a click game. If you don't put that piece exactly where it should be, it won't snap into place. This got annoying really often, really fast. 

The game also requires a lot of [u]tedious actions[/u] such as, clicking on a wrench a then drag it to a nut to unscrew it, then you have to click on the wrench again to do the exact mundane thing another 3 times. Why can't the wrench just stay at the cursor while you unscrew the all the nuts? 

The worst part comes after you complete a level, you get a "bonus" challenge. Where you have to fit an incomplete jigsaw pieces onto the picture. This part here; you can't save, you can't exit, you can't even bring up the game menu. You either finish it or ctrl+F4. Why would you do that? [u]Why remove the game menu[/u] especially at this part of the game?

So many baffling decisions. 

And extra bad point for just [u]terrible sound design.[/u] That music box chime to is on a loop for the entire game and it will drive you up the wall. The artwork, while looks good in an old-fashioned way, 
-------------
Final Words
-------------
I know there are some people who like this game. Hey you do you. There are a lot of other point and click puzzle games that have better art, better music, better story, better gameplay - Tiny Bang Story is not it. At least not for me, Not recommended.

[b]No, as a puzzle fan I don't recommend this to anyone. It looks, sounds nicely at first, but the puzzles going from calmly finding to straight trial & errors with brute-force clicking to the point of being tedious to play. [/b]

The first issue is the big picture pieces where some are cheaply placed as small sizes, and you already have to stress your eyes looking at small window of the game (no widescreen support or actually fullscreen at all). And for normal items to find, some could be placed in the same way, even worse when there are similar items yet clicking on them not counted.

The second one is the mini-games where a few are straight no clues to solve at all - for instance the water pipe, do the cranks stop or lead the flow of water? There is no telling because there is no animation! Even the hint ? guide further confuses you more; or the sudoku-like but ended up nowhere like sudoku and you can just guess the last 2 numbers instead. In addition, boring arcade mini-games. 

The third one is not having checkpoint, once you are ready to advance the game just moves you to the next level regardless of you having not completed collecting the big picture pieces, and there is no turning back but fresh new game. By that point you would end up not being able to finish the big picture, but it turned out you still gather them in full anyway, thus makes collecting the pieces pointless. 

Other than that, music turns dull quick, few imprecise control, glitch where clicking on humans after first time will now show you bubble hint unless you switch area and come back, and you cannot freely choose to replay any level but either start from scratch (which should be lengthy to reach the point you need) or just pick any of mini-games at the end.

Final score: 5/10 Mediocre.

88411890.review:
Luego de haber terminado este pequeño juego, las sensaciones son variadas. Pero para no extenderme demasiado, vamos al punto:

Lo mejor del juego sin duda es el estilo artístico, los dibujos, excelentes y una banda sonora realmente muy buena y relajante. También hay que rescatar que tiene cosas buenas y puzzles interesantes. De hecho sería un excelente juego, de no ser por las contras que van a continuación.

Entonces, vamos con lo malo del juego. Por empezar, ni bien instalarlo, la sensación es mala al tener el menú en inglés cuando la página dice que cuenta con dos millones de idiomas. Y alguno me dirá "es solo el menú, el resto del juego no tiene textos"; bueno, es verdad, pero ya que eran menos de diez palabras las podría haber traducido, o poner iconos que reemplacen las palabras, si lo quería hacer tan "universal". Pero esto es un detalle menor. Lo peor del juego es que jamás explica nada. Claro, si a uno le gustan éste tipo de juegos y es más o menos inteligente, no debería tener problemas, PERO, el juego hace todo lo posible por complicarte la existencia y estresarte a más no poder. De hecho, no es un juego casual para quienes quieran pasar un buen rato, sino para aquellos que quieran torturarse. Hay algunos puzzles con una dificultad ridícula, o directamente, que se resuelven sin explicación lógica aparente, y tenés que ir probando mil alternativas o mirar alguna solución en YouTube, como hice yo con algunos que me complicaron bastante. Y algunos dirán, "bueno, al menos lo termino para desbloquear los logros"... bueno, es que no tiene logros, y me dirán "entonces por la estadística, para tener un juego más terminado en la biblioteca", y es que al terminarlo, Steam tampoco lo detecta como un juego que haya sido completado. Por lo cual, salvo que realmente lo disfrutes (lo cual lo dudo bastante), es una pérdida de tiempo.

The Tiny Bang Story tiene (o tenía) todo el potencial para realizarse toda una franquicia con éste tipo de juegos, pero lamentablemente se quedó en el tiempo, jamás fue actualizado (olvidate de jugarlo en resolución de 1080p, y ni hablar de widescreen) y se nota mucho.

Por ahí está bueno para dárselo a tus hijos o sobrinitos a modo de castigo, para ponerlos en penitencia, los "amenazás" con ponerles este juego si se vuelven a portar mal. Quedate tranquil@ que se van a empezar a portar de maravilla... y de pasada capaz les estruja un poco el cerebro.

86425693.review:
[b]Intro[/b]

This is a puzzle game in which you have to find interactible objects, find related objects and complete mini-games and puzzles.

[b]Review[/b]

The game started out in a tiny window. Enlarging it moved it to the upper left corner. Even Borderless Gaming didn't work. Eventually somehow this corrected itself, but it is telling. Just like the options menu that just has two volume sliders. Or how incredibly long it takes to get to the main menu. I started clicking everywhere. Turns out, it just takes like half a minute for no reason.

The game itself is just bad. No story. No proper HOPs. Objects require laser precision. Interactible objects aren't indicated. Movement between the first and second screen requires pressing a button, waiting for a door to open then clicking. And this game requires you to constantly move between screens. At some point you have to use a wrench to unscrew bolts. It unselects the wrench after each use for no reason.

If you need any more indication of the incompetence of the developer: Using the hint button requires you to find and click on at least a dozen fireflies moving around the screen. No, i'm not joking. 78917224.review:
It's been out a while, but it's the first game I got on steam. I replay it once or twice a year.

It's charming, the art is consistent, music is fitting, items you needed to collect in one level appear as static scatter items in later levels, and there are little things you can click on just to play with. There's a subtle story too.

Now for the cons:

The hints are not directible. Sometimes I wanted to know about something besides the next puzzle piece!

Some of the collect or drag together parts are in mean places -  an elbow pipe, a train part, some tubing and a bobber come to mind...

Most of these puzzles are not unlike what you might see in an artifex mundi game, but those have better error tolerance - particularly on that compass puzzle. (this can be bypassed though!)

Potential ragequit puzzles include a compass dial, two "don't crash" minigames, a pipe puzzle, and putting tiles on a wall.

All those skypieces that look the same shade of blue. :)

Last room comes too early. But it was nice to be able to redo some of the puzzles.


There's also a missed opportunity here: Between the story told and the initial rate at which you assemble world sections, I expected two more levels in the middle to bring things full circle. - meets spouse in fountain park, then playing on beach with kids while gramma looks on like in the first picture. THEN the last room.

Perhaps the individual it was based on has not reached those points in their life yet.

I replay this a few times a year when it's been long enough to forget where everything is. There are other HOG games, but this one feels the most cohesive so far, and I come back to it.

74655103.review:
The Tiny Bang Story Review
Hours of fun in this relaxing brainteasing adventure.

Some key points that this game offers:
1.	A charming fantasy world to get lost in.
2.	Many challenging puzzles to test your wit.
3.	Various nooks and crannies to search and explore.

Gameplay & Controls:
The game is solely controlled with the mouse as a point and click game. You will navigate this world very easily with the mouse and there is no limit to the amount of clicks you can use which is nifty if you are a novice at this type of game. 
The gameplay is fairly straightforward. You are in a miniature fantasy world and need to collect and find certain objects to complete the given puzzles as you navigate to the next area with puzzle pieces being strewn across each area which you will need to collect to complete the final picture. 

Graphics:
The graphics are beautifully done and resemble illustrations in a storybook. Colibri games really went all out to create this whimsical little world with realistic aspects such as tassels that move when you run your mouse across them and hatches that open and close as they would in reality.
The weather resembles a beautiful sunny day, you can almost feel the warmth of the sun on you as you move from area to area. 

Sounds:
The music is soft and whimsical, though repetitive you won’t get sick of it playing softly in the background. 
As for the sounds they are cute and not overpowering. Each character has their own sound even though they don’t actually have lines they are more like interjections or exclamations but each one suits their respective character, another well thought out mechanic by the developer

Replayability:
The game might not offer much in terms of replayability, but as one has come to expect from these types of games, they can be replayed numerous times at your own leisure. That is what they were made for.
Casual fun that does not always require a lot of effort. 

MGR Gaming’s Conclusions:
Spoilers Ahead:
An absolute must play for the point and click or hidden object fans. Although a relatively short game, you will enjoy every moment spent on it; searching for lost things, solving puzzles, and generally just enjoying this absolutely beautiful Tiny World. 

This game suits you if you just want to relax your brain after a long day and looking for some casual fun. The puzzles are challenging to various degrees but none are too difficult.

At the end of the day, this genre of games is mostly for casual gamers that love this type of game, and then some gamers who enjoy casual time killers that doesn’t require too much effort. This is what we have here in ample quality supply. 

Score 8
By: LGRza
Date: 29 April 2011

Additional Info:
Platforms: PC: Mac: Linux
Genre: Point & Click: Hidden Object
Censor Rating: n/a
Age Rating: A
Developer: Colibri Games
Publisher: Colibri Games
Release Date: 22 April 2011

MGR Gaming Steam Curator:
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32364038/
MGR Gaming:
https://www.mgrgaming.co.za

72992652.review:
The Tiny Bang Story unlocks its array of logic puzzles and beautifully drawn hidden-object discoveries with an explosion of jigsaw-friendly relaxation.

WHAT I LIKED:
+ Over 20 different types of objects to find in the gorgeously designed backdrops, from over 100 jigsaw pieces to useful tools, which will help you progress.
+ 20 different mini-puzzles to challenge your logic solving capabilities, ranging from code-breaking sequences to complex tangrams.
+ Soothing score to relax the mind whilst you focus on the images in search of various objects.
+ Multi-profile saves, allowing every family member/friend to give this game a go.

WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE:
- The retro-inspired 2D side-scrolling minigames were tedious and slow. No checkpoints, meaning if you accidentally click one movement button too much, you have to start the 2-3 minute sequence over again.
- Too short (but oh so sweet!). With only 5 chapters, the game can be fully completed in less than 2 hours. The majority of hidden-objects were noticeable, meaning you could easily tackle each chapter in 20 minutes.
- The hint system is somewhat buggy (no pun intended considering one must collect mosquitoes to generate a hint...) and provides little to no help when activated.

VERDICT:
6/10 jigsaw pieces, now go and find them...

69044641.review:
[b]Pros[/b]
+60FPS
+Great art style
+Super chill music
+Great difficulty level

[b]Cons[/b]
+Short
+Game breaking bug possible in Level 3
+Some puzzles needed a short explanation
+No achievements

I really enjoy games like this. Chill music, puzzles, finding objects, nicely drawn art and a solid difficulty level. 

Tiny Bang Story is short, but it was easy to get hooked right away. Beautifully drawn art and the whole atmosphere is well done. There’s no dialog at all, just relaxing music while you progress through the game.

I initially thought this would be too easy but it does have some challenging puzzles and objects that are hidden very well. I would wonder HOW I missed several items when I swore I checked each screen thoroughly. Low and behold, I glanced over a well hidden piece. 

The puzzles are generally good. A few of them could use some direction, just a single sentence to tell the player the goal. I saw several unique puzzles and appreciated the variety. However, there is a game breaking bug if you are not careful. It’s with the compass and oven puzzle in Level 3. I was frustrated with being unable to complete the compass puzzle so I simply brute forced my way through the oven one. This works, but also takes away the ability to finish the compass puzzle so you are unable to finish the level. Several people in the game discussions had this issue, so glad I’m not the only one.

Another bug I encountered more than once was not collecting all the puzzle pieces but still finishing the level. If this happens to you, it’s ok and you’ll still get the required number of puzzle pieces to put together the main world. 


[b]Conclusion[/b]
A little more polish would have gone a long way. Still, Tiny Bang Story is worth playing.

[b]6/10[/b] Above Average

68453631.review:
The moment I started playing [I]The Tiny Bang Story[/I], I immediately thought of Amanita Design’s games, such as the [I]Samorost[/I] trilogy, [I]Machinarium[/I], [I]Botanicula[/I], and [I]Chuchel[/I]. It’s hard not to compare this game to those by Amanita Design, and to conclude that [I]TTBS[/I] could have been better.

That’s not to say that [I]TTBS[/I] is a horrible game. It’s not, but it’s mediocre at best and uninteresting at worst. [I]TTBS[/I] is a hidden object game, with the overall goal of collecting and reassembling all hidden jigsaw puzzle pieces to rebuild Tiny Planet. All the while, you’d need to solve a variety of other puzzles, for which you’d also need to find the hidden items. Thus, if you love hidden object games, you may find [I]TTBS[/I] more tolerable, if not appealing.

Yet, that is all there is to [I]TTBS[/I]. Throughout its 5 chapters, you find items, use the items to solve puzzles, reassemble the big jigsaw puzzle bit by bit, and move on to the next chapter. I was starting to get bored by the third chapter, after realizing that nothing amazing is ever going to happen. Aside from some swaying foliage, fluttering insects, and a few briefly-moving key objects, the world of Tiny Planet is pretty static. Even the residents you’d help along the way seem unmoved (ha!) by the disaster that had struck their world.

But, what about the puzzles? Not surprisingly, it’s the usual mixed bag of puzzles that involve swapping tiles, shifting marbles (I hate those), finding the correct number combinations, connecting pipes, completing arcade games, etc. I personally find it annoying when modern puzzle/adventure games do not incorporate puzzles organically, especially when they feature fantasy worlds like the one in [I]TTBS[/I]. Given the creative freedom that an imaginary world affords, it just seems lazy for the developers to simply shove all these puzzles in front of you as obstacles.

At one point during the game, I accidentally moved on to the next chapter without finding all hidden jigsaw puzzle pieces there. I thought I’d need to replay that part of the game. Yet (thankfully and mercifully?), I didn’t have to. The missing two pieces were given to me in the final jigsaw puzzle assembly. That led to think whether or not finding the jigsaw puzzle pieces is obligatory in each game chapter. If not, this makes the game more pointless and frustrating.

Still, I did enjoy the beautiful artwork by Eduard Harutyunyan, and the soundtrack by Strategic Music. Their work complement each other well, making me wish that [I]TTBS[/I] has a little something more (e.g. a simple story) to make the overall package more cohesive and meaningful. If you enjoy hidden object games, you may enjoy [I]TTBS[/I]. Otherwise, I think you may have a better time playing the Amanita Design games.

67514636.review:
I'm not a fan of both "hidden object" and "point and click" genres. Especially the first one, these games are either too easy (and therefore, boring) for me or too frustrating (mostly because of all damn pixel hunting you're required to do there). But Tiny Bang was cute and I got it on a big sale, so I decided to give it a chance. Well, I got almost exactly what I wanted... but it was a bit too short for my taste.

The Tiny Bang Story is a well-designed "hidden object"/puzzle game with nice graphics and fairly easy puzzles. There are two types of challenges: 1) collect some objects all over the level to do something, for example, fix a circuit; 2) complete a small simple puzzle to unlock something necessary to complete the level. The game consists of five big "levels", each level have four big screens, you can move between screens, sometimes you need to unlock the passage by doing something. There are 20 puzzles in total, and you can replay each one after completing the game. I guess I'll just list pros and cons here.

+: Cute, hand-drawn surreal design without glitches or objects that are out of place, nice animations. This game is actually very good for children with such design and decent puzzles which can be solved with the family.
+: Nice soundtrack, the game is really relaxing.
+: No pixel hunting. Everything is pretty much in plain sight, you only need to pay close attention to details, and collectable objects blend well with surrounding scenery.
+: The overall level of difficulty is pretty low, the game is available for everyone, all puzzles are unique. You can even get a very obvious hint for every task by collecting blue flies and filling hint meter.

-: The game is short. And I mean, really short for a game like this, if you count only the time I spent on the gameplay, without drinking tea or answering in chat, it was 2,5 hours. That was the biggest letdown for me, I thought that this game will have at least 8-10 more extensive levels.
-: The puzzles are really simple, if you are looking for a decent level of difficulty. The only one puzzle which could be called "complicated" among the ones I found there was "plumber" puzzle, where you need to close a net of pipes with only five valves. Everything else is very simple and pretty much obvious for a seasoned puzzle player.
- There are several moments where you don't really understand what to do next. You can understand, if you just try to click on the most obvious objects throughout the whole level, but still, this is a bit confusing. Also, the game has no proper ending - after completing the last part of the jigsaw puzzle in main menu you'll open a "dining room" where you can replay all puzzles one more time... and this is it. No final credits, no "the end", no indication that the game is cleared. This is confusing, too. And I didn't collect all puzzle pieces in the last level (somehow I still missed one) but everything was there in the menu. Erm... what's the point in collecting these, then?

All in all, this is a very nice game for relaxation, if you want to click on something without putting much strain on your eyes and mind. But I want more content here, otherwise it's even a bit overpriced for the full price. Someone can say that I am too greedy, but really, I want to see at least more story within this world if I'm buying this without the sale.

-----

If you are interested in other games I'm playing, check my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36682541-Lonely-Dev-Reviews/]Curator page[/url]. Maybe there will be something good for you.

67076883.review:
Short and simple. The visuals are beautiful and the calm sound track is fitting. It is a short game, and that is for the best as the gameplay isn't anything spectacular. The hidden objects are very well hidden, and the puzzles are all mostly very simple.

The story takes you through a number of locations following some-sort of worldly explosion that reduces the majority the areas to a bunch of puzzle pieces - in each area, find all the puzzle pieces and unlock the transportation to progress to the next area. Except it the puzzle pieces aren't necessary? The game seems to happily progress even if you don't find them all? All they seem to do is eat into the hints when you're looking for 24 balls to unlock the overly secure elevator.

Oh right, and there's no narrative, so its not a typical story per-say, its just a journey through a collection of surreal, picturesque landscapes revolving around a man. It doesn't really feel like there's a deeper meaning to it, which is fine - its a good way to spend a couple of hours clicking around.

One big drawback for me was that the game did not run in full-screen mode and the windowed mode could not be maximized or resized, so I ended up playing in a tiny window. There are no video settings beyond a full-screen toggle.

Overall, a pretty but rough game. At the low price and short play time I would argue that the whimsical audio and visuals are worth it.

The Tiny Bang Story is a point and click game full of various mini-games.
[b]+[/b] None of the mini-games are exactly the same, though puzzles are somehow of a common theme overall.
[b]+[/b] After beating the game, you can re-play any previous mini game, an option very rare but surely a welcome one.
[b]+[/b] Visuals are okay. The elements blend well with each other, yet they aren't very hard to distinguish.
[b]+[/b] The music's rather relaxing, it definitely fits with the rest of the game.
[b]±[/b] There are no achievement for it. But that also means you can play however you want and don't shy away from using in game tips.
[b]-[/b] Full screen doesn't adjust the resolution so choosing it when you have wide display will make everything look stretched and blurry.
[b]-[/b] I wish that they would use something other than insects as tips givers.
[b]-[/b] Contradictory to the name, there is no story. You just do puzzles to unlock more locations with even more puzzles.

64603900.review:
It is a hidden object game with some light puzzles. Looks alright. But I'm giving it a thumbs down, because technical issues and sketchy approach to art (no pun intended).

I played this game in the past on a different platform, didn't have issues. But playing it now on Steam I ran into game breaking bug. There was some silly crashing for me as well, but I found a solution on Steam forums, turns out at some point the game would crash if the sound is turned off. Should've been fixed by now, but it's not. Regarding the game breaking bug, looks like it might happen to anyone due to the way the game counts objects you need to find. It is possible to collect something, but the counter will not increase and you'll be effectively locked out of the progress further. No chapter replay or reset is provided, so the only way to dealing with such bug is replaying from the very beginning.

And as for the art, [url=https://artsammich.blogspot.com/2011/05/good-artists-borrow-great-artists-steal.html]apparently[/url] the game artist is quite frivolous with using other artists' works as references, and basically steals parts of their pieces.

Overall it feels like an attempt to cash in on Machinarium audience with somewhat dumbed down gameplay (hidden object instead of point-and-click adventure, although it still has mini-puzzles and mini-games). A fairly successful attempt at the time, I assume, despite the questionable choices of the artist. But a dated attempt as of today, mainly because of unaddressed technical issues.

62188603.review:
A really great little game that is kinda unique.  Lovely graphics and music.

You have to hunt for varying types of components either to help build/complete a machine or to give to a person who will then give you a reward that will help you on your way.    Whilst it is essentially a hidden object game it's not of the ilk that most are  There's no list of items to find as such, you'll be asked for example to find 8 gears or 12 little light bulbs and so on and all these things are cleverly disguised in the landscape and the objects it contains.  In between finding objects there are some tricky puzzle games to be completed.  Nothing too out of the ordinary but some more challenging than others.

A negative point I will raise that others have is that some puzzles use AWFUL COLOURS that are very close together which can make it nigh on impossible for colourblind people.    Dev's really need to stop doing this as it happens frequently.  Just use clearly contrasted colours like blue and yellow
 
Overall this is a thoroughly enjoyable game well worth the small fee.    I'm surprised the dev's haven't done more of these TBH.

60775225.review:
The Tiny Bang Story is basically an indie (independent) game. The general quality is relatively low, I truely believe it's quite the diamond in the rough.

The Big Bang Story is a point-and-click puzzle game.  The majority of the game involves you scrupulously scouring each level - collecting various random items that are required to progress to the next area.  Other puzzles range from mathematical equation solving to logic based. They all provide a nice break from the simple concept of searching for camouflaged items.

The first thing you will notice when you play this game is the level artwork. Each stage is beautifully hand drawn.  You can't help but pick up on and admire the detail that has been put in to the visuals. There are no horrible ghouls or sinister entities or dark and eerie environments. It is all very light-hearted and family friendly. Add this to calming and pleasant soundtrack.

The Tiny Bang Story is rather short with there not being much in terms of replayability. Regardless of this, it is an interesting, fresh and relaxing ride for the duration. If you are a fan of point-and-click ‘hidden-item-locating' games, I highly recommend this game.

[b]Pros[/b]
-  Beautiful artwork
-  Relaxing fun
-  Not too difficult

[b]Cons[/b]
-  Way too short
-  Not much replayability
-  Simplicity not for all

[b]Overall Rating[/b]
7/10

Decent point and click game.

+ Nice music. (the whole game has only 2 tracks though)
+ Huge variety in puzzles.

- Greatly painted level design. Full of details, but some of it are stolen... Appearently some of the art styles this game uses are ripped-off other artists work.
- Beginning is really cryptic. There is a "tutorial" which points a few things to collect and that's it.
- Most of the game is finding missing thing in levels and just collecting them. In other words most of the gameplay is "Where's Waldo?" just instead of Waldo you collect things which are needed for puzzles.
- Some puzzles are painful. Game does not explain what is needed to be done, there is a hint given for each puzzle of what to do (yes not a hint for solution, but a hint for what you're supposed to do) and sometimes it's not enough to understand what I need to do.
- You need to collect 30 beetles to get a hint. 30, it takes quite long. If I am going for a hint anyway why 5 or atleast 10 can't be enough? 30 just takes a much longer time to collect and does not create any challenge of any sort.
- Hyping progress which leads to pretty much nothing.
- Ending. Game does not even show the developer credits. It just ends.


6/10

59050915.review:
[h1]Short, simple, pleasant[/h1]

These are definitely adjectives that describe this game. The Tiny Bang Story is the first game of the Colibri Games studio. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game tests our perceptiveness and makes us solve quite simple puzzles. Our goal is to finish five boards and create a map of the puzzles that we will get during the game.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Music is calming and pleasant, but it also makes you sleepy. You can't say much about the soundtrack because of the length of the game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The graphics are pleasing to the eye, but it is nothing special. 

[h1]Summary[/h1]

The Tiny Bang Story is a good game and very short so you can finish it in one evening. However, puzzles are mostly trivial and it can be more difficult to find a variety of well hidden items.
[b]
✔️Pleasant gameplay
✔️A pretty good soundtrack
✔️Nice graphics
✔️Cheap

❌Too short
❌Too easy riddles.

54624102.review:
The Tiny Bang Story was really fun to play and easy to pick up on. It had a pretty simple concept that made it easy to understand. Some of the puzzles were a little confusing and weren't easy to solve on your own because you weren't really given instructions. If anything this is my biggest issue with the game, but I do love it nonetheless.

I used this game to get my grandma into videogames because its easy to play and relatively challenging for someone new to games. It helped her get used to mouse control among other things, but I really am proud of her for completing it.

The one discouraging thing I came across were several bugs. This other guy said not to give this game a chance because of them. I disagree, but they can be frustrating for any player.

Our two biggest issues were issues with the game crashing on start sometimes, and with the game being impossible to use on fullscreen at certain points, where clicking in some places would literally close the game. It did suck that she had to not play on fullscreen, and that I had to prepare her for some possible bugs and issues, but the game was relatively comprehensive and enjoyable. And at the end of the day, its worth a play if you buy it on sale, or need a good but relaxing puzzle game.

Don't be discouraged, but yeah, if you're not willing to put up with a bug or two, this game is not for you.

49968023.review:
I really don't know how I feel about Tiny Bang Story. 

It's got a nice art style and relaxing vibe. In the main it's a "find an object" game with a variety of puzzles thrown into the mix; my issue is some of the puzzles are just not fun. Getting completely stuck on a couple of them, I accepted defeat and went online only to find I would never have solved them. I'm not smart enough to enjoy the game it seems!

The "find an object part" of the game is actually more fun than I thought. Jigsaw pieces and other objects are camoflaged so well in the background you could swear there is no more to find until you see it from the corner of your eye. In that way, this game really does sharpen your observation skills. 

When it's fun it's quite nice, but when it's not I found it horrible. If you aren't precious about getting solutions when you get stuck, or simply smarter than me, I think on balance you'll enjoy it.

A tentative recommend.

49655809.review:
[h1]Plenty of bang, not much story![/h1]
Tiny Bang Story makes it pretty clear from the start that it is a puzzle game, as the world itself is shattered into a jigsaw puzzle. What we get winds up being a bit of a mixture of all kinds of puzzle games that really aren't bad, but really aren't much of a challenge.

The execution of the hidden objects part of this game varies quite a lot between really easy and a bit cheesy. A barely visible outline of a puzzle piece is hidden like a speck in a busy background, feeling cheap and artificially difficult. Most of the rest of what you will find stands out enough that you won't miss them, but in some cases will want to remember where you'd seen them.

The logic puzzles were a lot more fair, and mostly quite easy as well. Some of them seemed more about testing the player's patience rather than their wits, others were trial and error. Some had no direction at all, and while I really enjoy this approach, leaving the player to figure out what to do, I can see how this might frustrate some. Fortunately there is a help stem in the game, and some users have posted guides in case you become confused about what to do next.


My monitor is large and has a slightly higher DPI, making this game appear really tiny on screen in widowed mode. In full screen the game was washed out, stretched horizontally, and fuzzy. Any option to adjust the resolution would have been appreciated.

I liked the art style in this game, which reminded me of illustrated story books I read as a child.

The music was pretty relaxing, if a bit repetitive. I actually found it very fitting for this game's tone and relaxed pace. The sound effects were also good, if a bit generic.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Simple to get into
    [*]Hand drawn art style
    [*]Intuitive puzzles
    [*]No hand holding
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Lacks challenge
    [*]No resolution options
    [*]Some puzzles are tedious
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 06/10[/b]

An easy to play game that feels made for kids and entry level hidden object game players. A decent family friendly experience.

So, we have a little hidden object game here. The graphics are quite nice, nothing to complain here.

The main reason why I'M giving this a "thumbs down" is that quite a bit of the feedback here made me believe this is more than just a hidden object game. Actual riddles, even tricky ones to solve. I played through the whole game and yes, there are some mini games, a few of which you might even use a minimum of brains on. But mostly, they are very straight forward, solvable by "brute force" (i.e., try and error) in a short time or on a childish level like "navigate a ship through a level" - with up and down arrows that you even need to click on.

Now the trouble is, what's left is a hidden object game, nothing more, nothing less. It's short but with nice graphics. If you like that, you can take your chance with this. I'd recommend getting it on advertisement though, I don't think it's worth 5 bucks.
But unfortunately, I had hoped for more - so don't let yourself be fooled it is like I was.

I like playing puzzle games that give you a challenge and have some interesting riddles. I also like when those games have a nice background story and, if the graphics are good, I really enjoy the experience.

Having said this, I disliked almost every minute of playing this game.
That's mainly because the puzzles are very easy, not really original since the same type has been seen in other games for who knows how long. That means that most of your time is just spent scanning the screen for a hidden item so that you can solve the puzzle, which after finding the item happens pretty much instantly. 
I have 9 hours of playtime... thank goodness I didn't pay for this game. I don't mind paying for a game I enjoy, but a game that doesn't even get you to play over 10 hours? Not really worth it I'd say. Comparing this with an A-class game that costs maybe 20€ and easily gives you more than a hundred hours or gaming, this game does not seem appealing at all in this area either.

If you enjoy being a hidden item hunter, go ahead and have fun. If you like interesting and challenging puzzles, save your money or go ahead and become terribly bored (at least it will be over soon).

As a whole, this game is a 3/10.

47488879.review:
I wasn't sure, whether I will find game of this genre enjoyable, however The Tiny Bang Story had quickly changed my mind. Even made me heavily engaged into resolving the puzzles & riddles. I consider this game as a short break from bigger titles, but with quite huge brain training potential. Here we go then:

Storyline: 7/10

You're probably asking if there is any story in a puzzle game, but yes it is. Not a complicated one, but each level is tied to another and all are making one story. Quite nice story to be honest, that is stuck somewhere in the background, which makes solving the riddles have some point at all. I'll give it 7/10, because the story is logical and it is there, most of puzzle games don't have any story in the background at all.

The World: 8/10

Another section that is a suprise for puzzle game. However this title has such original and cozy world, that it is worth mentioning. It is even worth 8 points out of 10, because world presented here takes main idea from the "The Little Prince" story. You are playing on a very small planet (though bigger than in mentioned book) which has a lot of very pleasant places. So, suprisingly, a puzzle game gets higher grade for presented world, than many games that should have this thing made really better.

Graphics: 8/10

Very nice graphics to look at, warm & cozy to be honest - makes you feel like you are at home, solving the real-world 1000 pieces puzzle. The graphics are also clear for your eyes, I mean, all elements that can be interacted with are easily spotted, though sometimes demanding. It's very well balanced and deserves 8/10 grade.

Sound & Music: 6.5/10

Sound effects are made perfectly, they don't exhaust you and perfectly pretend real life sounds. But music. Music... It's good - but only in the first hearing. Every replay of each song makes it worse and worse. I've spent like 3 hours in this game and I really don't want to hear its soundtrack again for the next year. Or decade. Or century...

Interface: 10/10

As I've mentioned in the beginning, I would have never thought that I would have been so engaged by puzzle game. But the mechanics of this game, and riddles included there are so good that I've stopped playing any other games - I just wanted to solve all the things this Tiny Bang threw at me. Sure, some puzzles were really hard for me, e.g. [spoiler] some Leonardo Da Vinci math riddle and map of Earth with colours [/spoiler], and I must confess: I've used walkthrougs for these two, but every riddle is different from other and worth solving. So I think I'll give 10/10 for this section, as this game really shines for its genre basics.

Overall: 8/10

That's it. If you are looking for puzzle game you've came to the right neighbourhood my friend - buy this game and you will not be disappointed.

The Tiny Bang Story feels like a hidden object game from before hidden object games became such a well-defined genre. The story is muted at best, the puzzles are surprisingly varied, and interaction can be sluggish and unresponsive. Imagine my shock upon discovering this game is only seven years old.

Unearned aging aside, the game is as gorgeous as it looks in screenshots. At times, it's difficult to tell what can be interacted with and what can't be, but it's always a pleasure to look at either way. For the most part, this game is just relaxing puzzles, with some soothing music and some beautiful art direction. But I can't really find anything to recommend about the game. It's essentially just a collection of puzzles you'd find in a Highlights magazine. Or you could just find online for free. Also, I feel a number of the puzzles have frustrating elements. For example, after every section, you are given puzzle pieces, which you have to assemble. But the puzzle pieces are all shaped the same, which gets irritating when you have to brute force a dozen identical blue pieces that represent the sky. That's not fun; that's a chore.
As mentioned elsewhere, there is a lot of pixel hunting, which can likewise get frustrating at times. Like, "Oh you haven't found all the pieces to this machine? That's because the final piece was a random clickable part of the instructions!" Most of the game is just finding objects in a scene, which CAN be relaxing, but all too often falls under frustrating to me.
Lastly, this isn't a knock on the game, but the world that it presents looks interesting and rich for potential stories, but the game itself has no story as far as I can tell. This seems like a missed opportunity.
I wouldn't recommend purchasing this game. Not because it's bad, but because there's just nothing to set it apart from better implemented puzzle games that you can find elsewhere.

46669648.review:
The Tiny Bang Story is a short point & click game that will allow you several hours of gameplay through the search of hidden objects and the solving of different puzzles.

While the title suggests that there will be a story involved, there isn't really much of one. The entire story is that the world has literally fallen to pieces and you must put them back together. There are five sections of the game that you work through and all the while you must be on the lookout for puzzles pieces that are strewn across all of the different sections of the little world. At the end of each level, you use all of the puzzle pieces that you've collected in that area to continue to put the world back together in the form of a jigsaw puzzle. Other than that, there is very little else in the way of a storyline.

In total, there are twenty puzzles that are unique. There is also the ongoing jigsaw puzzle that I mentioned before to work on throughout the entire game. While a few of the puzzles can be a bit confusing, most of them are able to solved without too much difficulty. They are all generally relaxing to work through, with the exception of those few that are on the more difficult side.

While you are continuously searching for puzzle pieces, you also must search for objects that will allow you to unlock the different puzzles. These objects are usually easy to spot, with a few that are a little on the tricky side. For those that are harder to find, you can use hints that you've earned by collecting little bugs that fly around the world. They saved me from total frustration more than once.

The art style is absolutely charming. I am not usually one for caring too much about the visual art in games but I found the style here to be quite endearing. It surely helps with the overall relaxing atmosphere of the game, along with the gentle music that plays in the background.

This is a must have for all who love hidden object games. I don't often play them anymore, but this brought back the memories I have of playing them when I was younger. I highly recommend it, even at full price.

45634695.review:
[b]6/10[/b] - Playable, relaxing aesthetic but lacks context to the majority of its puzzles.

[u]I got the game for free from a limited time offer.[/u]

Enjoyable basic puzzle game but my only big complaint is the lack of information.

This game uses the typical point-and-click gameplay of old where you just have to guess what the game wants.

That being said, everything the game wants you to do makes sense (unlike other point-and-click games), but it just doesn't tell you [b]why[/b] you need to solve those puzzles. Once you can wrap your head around the logic of the game and fill in the gaps, you can move quickly through the levels with exception of 1 or 2 puzzles within each level that you may or may not understand and if you do, you may not know how to solve it or what the game wants exactly for you to solve the puzzle. 

[u]I've had to look up a walkthrough for every level of the game.[/u] Even when I knew the solution, it was never a "Ohhhh I'm an idiot" moment, it was more of a "okay then..." moment. It's not the most difficult point-and-click game out there, it just severely lacks references for you to understand what the game wants. Sometimes it is plain and simple, other times it's deceiving (compass puzzle, water pipes puzzle) and then there are puzzles that just feel like busy work. (fishing lure puzzle, image shitfing puzzles)

If the game added a little more context it would be more enjoyable and less confusing. It may take some of the difficulty away, but at least it wouldn't be as frustrating.

All that done though, the aesthetic of the game is pleasing and calm. It is definitely a game that's designed to be calm and relaxing. So although there is frustration, there's never a rush to beat the game. This is probably the best thing this game has done. It is rewarding to beat each section of the levels just again, it doesn't always feel fair. 

For the price of $5, I wouldn't complain too much. I have 7 hours in the game so just figure your window is anywhere from 5 - 10 hours. There's probably better games out there for the same price that will offer you more play time.

Fairly satisfying hidden object game with minor puzzles. I like the presentation. 45431394.review:
Para quien no quiera leer el análisis completo dejo un resumen con pros y contras al final de él

UNA COLORIDA AVENTURA HIDDEN OBJECT

Historia: Técnicamente, no hay como tal. Estas en un pequeño planeta en el que vas a tener que solventar puzzles y buscar objetos para poder seguir avanzando por este. Son 5 partes del planeta a explorar.

Jugabilidad: Es una aventura hidden object. Estas en un planeta con puzzles a resolver y cientos de objetos que buscar.Una vez consigas todo, pasas a la siguiente pantalla, tras realizar un pequeño puzzle que existe entre pantallas, que básicamente es ir montando el planeta con las piezas que vas encontrando. Repites el proceso 5 veces, y terminas el juego. 

Respecto a la duración, me ha llevado 3 horas. Hay un par de puzzles un poco liosos, pero por lo demás, no te quedarás atascado. Aparte de que hay un asistente de ayuda en el caso de que hiciese falta.

Gráficos: Está todo hecho a mano con una posterior digitalización. El planeta es muy colorido, y tiene una atmósfera entrañable. Para el tipo de juego que es, encajan bien.

Sonido: La banda sonora está bien. No son muchos temas, pero ambientan perfectamente el juego.

El juego no tiene voces ni subtítulos. Los únicos rótulos que verás son los del menú. Si hablas con los pocos habitantes existentes, te indicarán sus puzzles mediante viñetas.

No he visto ningún bug y el juego tiene cromos, para quien pueda interesar.

En resumen, The Tiny Bang Story es una aventura Hidden Object, colorida, entrañable y sencilla, que te hará pasar un tranquilo y buen rato.

PROS
+ La atmósfera del juego está bien. Sencilla y colorista a más no poder, te ayudará a pasar un rato tranquilo
+ Los puzzles son entretenidos, sin tener excesiva dificultad

CONTRAS
- La duración y la sencillez por ponerle alguna. Dentro de este género hay propuestas más completas


NOTA: 7. Si te gustan las aventuras hidden object, no tienes mucho tiempo y quieres jugar tranquilo, este es tu juego. Hay propuestas más elaboradas dentro del género, pero este merece una oportunidad.

45319245.review:
This is how memorable TINY BANG STORY is: I played the demo yeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeears ago, I mean, probably during the heyday of JayIsGames. And yet, when RPS (I think) announced that it was free for a day a few months back, I knew *exactly* the game they wre talking about and still had pretty accurate memories of what the first scenes of the game looked like. 

This is a hidden object game done right: the things you collect aren't random knickknacks stuck in a swamp or whatever, but interactors with the enivornment that help you solve gentle puzzles.

Now, while it's beautiful, it's not quirky-funny or mournful like Amanita Studios' games (BOTANICULA and MACHINARIUM in particular), but like a lullabye, a great before-bed play: it also has one of the most soothing soundtracks I've heard of late.

Is does get a little repetitive as time moves on, and it can be frustrating scouring each environment for piece 10 when you've already got the other 9.  But that's a hidden object game for you.

A highly recommended gentle puzzler.
*  * *
After completing the game, I'd like to amend my review. By the end of this game, it was getting tedious, samey. It wasn't just scouring the screens, but also how un-fun puzzle types (8-bit minigames) were recycled...Rather than every level having its own character, each level was built on the same template of puzzles.
Without extra things to interact with (scenery bells you can't ring), and puzzles that were frustratingly underclued (water puzzle in the last level), the charm started to wear off. I was glad when it ended and did not stick around for the bonuses.
Holistically, the Amanita studios games are of better quality. TINY BANG still does some things right, but my verdict is "a gentle, but at times tedious puzzler, somewhat recommended."

45288126.review:
I've never written a review for Steam before. But I had to today. Just...my feelings are so strong I feel I have to.

From an objective standpoint, it's a very good game. Well crafted, and you can tell a lot of love went into it. I feel a lot of people could enjoy this game. So take this as less of a 'negative review' and more an angry person's warning about what to be wary of.

90% of this game is spent scouring the 3 screens at your disposal for 10 of something. You'll get a quest to find this many of this thing, take it back, then solve a puzzle or give it to a person. Do this enough and in the right order, you get to move on. No inventory management or item puzzles. While games don't need that to be fun, this one just feels like a really frustrating 'Spot the Difference' game with no second picture to cross-reference.

The single most frustrating part is how the things you need are always in the world, and you can see them as soon as you start the level. But you can't actually pick them up unless you have the quest that requires them. And did I mention that they're practically painted into the background sometimes? Because they are. Finding 20 marbles wouldn't be nearly as hard if they didn't put them on traffic lights to hide them. Also, each level has, like, 30 puzzle pieces in it, and finding all of them grants you access to the next level. Since these pieces are so crucial, it sure is great that they're invisible half the time! That, or they're super tiny, stashed away where you can't see them.

Another really infuriating part is how, on multiple occasions, the game will ask you to find a certain number of cogs. But there's these drains on the ground that look EXACTLY like the cogs you're looking for. So you spend a large chunk of time trying to get the game to register your click, only to discover you were supposed to pilfer the one from the telescope.

A lot of puzzles come down to guesswork and just trying stuff hoping it will work. Some of them don't have a clear goal from the get-go, some of them seem designed to frustrate you, and a couple I couldn't figure out even when I had the hint box open.

Oh, yeah. There's a hint box. But it doesn't help when it will give you a wrong answer, then YOU have to reverse-engineer what they want you to do. Yeah, chances are, guys, that if I open the hint box, I'm already at my wit's end and really need a boost. You know. A HINT.

In levels 2 and 3, there are these painfully slow Atari style minigames that take like 5 years to complete and are mandatory. If you mess up once, you're dead and have to start from the beginning. They're not entertaining, and seem specially crafted to make me mad. There's also a puzzle during the first level, fresh out of the tutorial, that had no clear goal at all. Once I finally figured out what to do by happenstance, it was so easy. But getting there drove me up the wall.

The fullscreen function didn't work properly for me. I had to play the whole game in a tiny window. Again, spot the difference game with tiny differences and no reference picture. It's like the world's worst game of I SPY. The options menu is pitiful, just volume and semi-functional fullscreen. Don't even think about playing this game if you're colorblind. A puzzle in the 1st level requires color matching, as does the 2nd. And you'd never be able to find the puzzle pieces.

I could go on and on about how one NPC asked me to get three apples but didn't give me a quest for it, meaning I couldn't collect them and had to click on a completely different part of the level to continue. Or how your main character is apparently a witch as they refuse to touch even the slightest bit of water to get a key. Or how one puzzle was literally just spinning a couple of compasses around until they line up (spoiler alert, they never do). Or how infuriating the jigsaw portions are, because 2/3 of the pieces you have are of the sky and all look the same. But I think I've overstayed my welcome as-is.

In conclusion, I hate this game. And it hates me.
