45286016.review:
As beautiful as this game is, it fails miserably as being a [i]good game.[/i] The art design is inspired, the music is relaxing and perfectly fitting, and the story that seems to unfold through progression is, if not not gripping, then at least something to look forward to uncovering more details of.

Beyond all of that, though, the game has some rather glaring design-holes that keep me from enjoying it. The first is one of that same thing that plagues the Pixel Hunt sub-genre, in that you can't go two steps without wanting to tear out your hair for that [b]one last puzzle piece[/b]. The game hides puzzle pieces and collectibles well within the scenery, sometimes only a few pixels wide, demanding you comb through every scene with a fine-toothed comb, often when you've already cleared the screen, and it turns out your princess is in another castle.

Luckily the music "facilitates" this, being relaxing and just long enough that it doesn't drive you crazy, but you'll get fed up with the game nonetheless.

Little Bang Story's hint feature alleviates the issue by pointing out the exact location of any remaining collectibles on-screen...with the caveat that it [b]only[/b] points out collectibles that are [u]on-screen[/u], [i]once[/i], and even then for every time you want to use the feature, you have to play a mind-numbing "minigame" involving the capture of little on-screen flies. You need to collect dozens of them as they slowly spawn, and you can spend upwards of a minute just getting a single hint. Then you might need to do it again and again until you find the last piece... That is, if you're on the correct screen to begin with. Since each stage has 4+ screens, and hints do not transfer between screens. The result is that you might spend upwards of 5 minutes collecting little bugs just to find a single missing collectible!

And speaking of mind-numbing mini-games, LBS boasts having "over 30 exciting brain teasers", which roughly translates to having dozens on repetetive puzzles or click-the-balloon minigames that add little to the game, sometimes subtracting worth through sheer bad and/or utterly boring design(looking at you, boat-minigame!). Some of them are okay, but many  are also just "put the picture back together" type things, sort of like...

Jigsaw puzzles! They're littered through this game and come in many variants. From "torn picture" types, to sliding-block pictures, to strange transformative ones. By far the worst offender(unless you like them) is the single instance of a "normal" jigsaw puzzle. Throughout the game you pick up little puzzle pieces hidden in the environment, and at the end of a level you get to put the [i]next[/i] stage back together on the overworld. Putting it together wouldn't be so bad, except the game also animates the existing world, so it alters the edges, "lying" to you about which piece should fit where. Exacerbating this is that it's also one of those jigsaw puzzles that makes you put together the "sky", blurring blues and greys that seemingly go into the puzzle at random.

So if you think you can enjoy or work around and of the above issues, go right ahead. But for the rest of you, don't waste your time with this game.

45235072.review:
What a shame...

Beautiful graphics, nice idea, and some clever puzzles - but overall poorly executed, resulting in a confused, and frustrating mess.  When I first started playing, I was loving it - the first couple of levels were a joy to play, and the hint system (which requires an element of grind in order to get the hint) was a nice touch; frustrating enough to put me off reaching out for a hint, but simple enough to mean that when I really couldn't find that last piece of pipe, I had help at hand.  Sadly, the game went from an enjoyable brain-teaser challenge, to a painful chore and the need to fight the temptation to google answers.  This game came so close to being fantastic, but failed toward the finish.

- Puzzle pieces to be collected on each level actually don't seem to have any effect, and it is astoundingly easy to irreversibly leave a level without intending to and without all puzzle pieces - despite the missing puzzle pieces, this seems to have no impact on the putting together of the jigsaw planet after the level!  Leaves you wondering why we are collecting the pieces in the first place.
- Some of the later puzzles make no sense.  I understand that the puzzles should get more complex as the game progresses, but given the lack of any text (which is a really nice gameplay feature!) and no contextual clues (and some very bizarre hidden requirements) some puzzles end up being unpleasantly frustrating, and actually unsolvable based only on the clues to hand - in hindsight, they always make sense, but before knowing the answer there simply isn't enough information to rely on.  I don't mean like the 'Tetris piece' puzzle, which I found excrutiatingly difficult, but at least knew what to do and had to assume there was a correct layout of the pieces (which there was).  I mean like the 'compass alignment' puzzle, which freely allowed turning of the dial either clockwise our counter-clockwise, but which (for some unknown reason) required that you only turn it counter-clockwise.  If you set off attempting to achieve the seemingly simple solution, but happened to turn clockwise, you're doomed to half an hour of cursing at why the whole thing is lining up but not being counted as completed.  Bug, design fault, or intentional difficulty - I don't know, but - it's bad.  Also, the water pipes - I could understand the 'idea' behind the solution - using just 5 valves achieve a certain water course - but with no information on which direction the water is travelling, or whether the wheels would open or close the valve they were attached to, made what could have been an enjoyable head-scratcher into a disappointingly dull grind.
- Some of the puzzle design felt like it had been given up on.  Earlier in the game, you would discover a puzzle which first required pieces to be collected (such as light bulbs, pieces of pipe, or dice)  and once these were put into the puzzle, you had to then solve the puzzle.  Later, you collect clock hands and numerals, and find that as soon as you add them to the clock face not only is that puzzle solved, but that whole level is done - and without a hint of anything resembling a departure (like an elevator, plane or boat) you leave the 'level' and the game is done.

Frustrated & disappointed...

45180311.review:
The only real reason to play this is for the absolutely glorious orchestral soundtrack that plays while you reassemble the jigsaw puzzle of the scattered world.

And seeing how that track has been publicly free for a while, that means there's no reason to play it.

It's a hidden-object game, and is probably the first such one that I ever completed in my life to my memory, and certainly not without a walkthrough. The story was just irksome[spoiler]; there is zero explanation of how the world scattered into jigsaw pieces upon the events of the opening, or where you even are, given how the planet is disassembled[/spoiler]. The arcade games[spoiler]with the boat and plane[/spoiler] are really tediously long. Some items are pixel-hunt-like. I resorted multiple times to randomly clicking around constantly to catch things I might have missed (and yes, it did work at least once, which is a sign of a [i]badly made[/i] hidden-object game).

Being a newbie to hidden-object games, I think the only initially cool thing about this is that as you progress through its four levels or so, you sometimes receive tasks as you click on stuff, to now retrieve, say, spheres or something, which causes you to backtrack and revisit certain areas. That was interesting enough, but the game made me feel like a horrible kleptomaniac as I was literally pulling things off of other buildings to use as makeshift rungs for a ladder, for example, lol. There was one cool mouse effect (ropes would ambiently sway a little bit as you brushed them over with your mouse without any clicking needed), but everything else was just carried entirely by the art and music. Even speaking as a professional in the arts world, that's not quite good enough reason to rate a game highly, IMO.

The built-in independent puzzles were decent enough, but I'd still warn to only get this for free, if even that.

45119841.review:
A great "small" puzzle/point and click game!

The Tiny Bang Story begins with the world shattering into pieces... puzzle pieces and its up to you to rebuilt the planet and restore the land. Each of the playable levels each has a goal to achieve to proceed to the next level and you also collect puzzles pieces to rebuild the world as you proceed. 

Each level has the same goal, click certain items to get a quest, find all the quest items, and place them in the right area to complete or access a puzzle. However, finding some of these items can be a total pain to find as they A. fit in with the surrounding way to well or B. they are way to small or very obscured by objects to even see. Lucky, you have some... Blue Fireflies? The game never really tells you what they are. and collecting enough of these will let it help you find one of the items. I do also to have criticize on some of the puzzles difficulty, and the collectable puzzle pieces with seems to absolutely nothing once I left a stage missing just one and being able to proceed. All the puzzles have variety, which is great! ranging from building contraptions to guiding vehicles. The presentation is absolutely beautiful with some of the prettiest graphics for a puzzle game I have seen and including a very relaxing soundtrack to boot. 

Overall, The Tiny Bang Story is a great puzzle game with amazing visuals, a great soundtrack, and, of course, enjoyable puzzles. its just a shame there isn't that much post-game content after when you complete this extremely fun game.

45030884.review:
tl;dr version:
Pretty looking hidden object type game, seriously held back by technical issues.

Long version:
Yep, it's hidden objects. Click pictures to collect stuff, find and solve puzzles. It looks good and sounds nice, but... that's where things end unfortunately.
Playing full-screen is a no-go, you're still stuck with a small drawing area surrounded by massive black borders. And also the mouse cursor goes jittery and the game regularly fails to respond to clicks.
Windowed mode is not much better, as there's still some puzzles and minigames that don't respond very well.
Story is... a lot more vague than it needs to be. You go to a few different worlds, visit a few people, jigsaw the world back together and then basically nothing happens. hum.
Add in an objective to collect said jigsaw pieces, which are mostly pretty well hidden, which you can just skip past.
There's also one of the more clumsy hint systems in the genre: click 30 flying bugs, then click the hint button to watch a bug slowly fly towards a point of interest. Accidentally click somewhere before the bug gets there and do that all over again.
Those hint bugs will also go and point out the ultimately useless jigsaw pieces for good measure.
To top things off, the objectives per scene/stage/level also appear to be fairly random, again probably because the narrative to go wth the surreal images decides to not make sense.

This then hits a bottom line where something that looks like it should be interessting enough, just isn't. Instead it becomes a short-ish, and somewhat boring trip to nowhere.

44956196.review:
A nicely drawn hidden object game which introduces an elemnt of puzzles. Some puzzles need to be completed to receive a piece to complete another puzzle. The music is pleasnt, and even after time does not become irritating. The imagery is nicely drawn and a good deal of thought and effort has been put in to hiding the pieces.
Most of the mini-game puzzles offer a casual challenge, while others are simply jigsaws.
However the game is seriously marred by a number of ill-thought puzzles and design flaws. Firstly a number of puzzles are colour based, and given the pastel colour scheme this makes the gameplay inaccessible to colourblind users. There are no options to assist those with colour-deficient sight. This leads to an incredibly frustrating experiece. There is one "puzzle" where you play that colour memory game "Simon". Infuriatingly, a mistake made can leave you having to start all over again, and the number or successes needed to complete the puzzle is too much to even stand a chance of "being lucky". There isn't even an option to skip a puzzle if you fail it several times. Another colour puzzle gives you six pastel colours, and you have to sort and arrange squares of differing shades/saturation into order for the parent colour. Practically impossible for a colourblind user, even with a walkthrough to hand. (If you don't understand why this is difficult, set your display to back and white, and see how well you manage).
A number of the puzzles offer no explanation as to what is required to complete them, and the in-game help system for these puzzles is also inadequate. One such puzzle is the fountain pipes.
Lastly, there are hidden jigsaw pieces to collect, which are challengingly hidden. However collecting these pieces serves no purpose. You can complete a level without warning, and not having collected all the pieces. There is no penalty for not collecting all the pieces, which sort of makes this game element pointless. With regards to completing a level without warning, you can't go back to replay, or finish collecting puzzle pieces.
The very last level is another element of confusion. With just two rooms, there appears to be nothing to collect, and you're presented with all the mini-game puzzles you've encountered so far, and it's not clear what you're required to do.  It seems this level is not a level, but simply there to offer you the chance to replay puzzles from the game. This is rather disapionting because it's dressed up as a level, which it isn't, and replaying the puzzles in this way serves no real purpose i.e. completing the puzzles in a faster time. You might as well replay the entire game. Other games simply offer this kind of replay function from the game menu once the game has been complete.

This game was made available for free in the Steam Store.

44948326.review:
Excellent game. It takes the 'hidden object' genre and completely re-invents it to be a more cohesive story narrative and much more compelling to play. The puzzles are not too difficult and unlike other point and click games the puzzles make sense and with a bit of brain power you could figure out the solutions without resorting to online guides. Other similar games have puzzles that are so convoluted and illogical it's almost impossible to figure them out through natural lateral thinking. In this, the puzzles feel organic and more importantly, fair. 

The lack of text only compliments the accessiblity of the game. It doesn't bog you down with unnessasary walls of text or tutorials. Easy to understand picture prompts may nudge you in the right direction should you get a bit stuck but in my playtime I've never been so stuck that I felt frustrated and needed anything more than a little bit of determination. 

Excellent game and highly recommended.

44930169.review:
Such a magical and ecnhanting game. You get no violence, no combat, no fancy visual effects and none of the other gaming commodities of today either. What you do get however, is a superbly pretty, hand drawn world which has an atmosphere that engages your inner child and imagination. This is only enhanced by the stellar music that accompanies your adventures (which is free to download, check the game news feed)! The scenes look like pages from one of your first books.

If I'd have to, I'd compare this to a toy from your childhood you just stumble upon as an adult to your surprise. When you take it in hand, all of your mature life just zaps away and you are left with your dreamy, hazy memories from your early years when your fantasy was running wild creating worlds, characters and stories. You hold this toy in your hands and just let your longing for fairy worlds take over, sentimentally remembering the cozy feelings of summers past when you were very small and everything was it's own miracle. This is what it feels like to play this game.

I get that folks with normal color vision can easily overlook how many colorblind people exist. However, the third stage has a puzzle which could credibly be used as a test for colorblindness. I doubt this is an accident. The creator of this game obviously just doesn't care.

On the plus side, at least I didn't pay for it. If I had, I'd refund it.

Beyond that, the puzzles aren't especially interesting and the hint system is made arbitrarily obnoxious by forcing you click on many tiny, moving insects in order to get a hint. But if you need a hint on an actual puzzle rather than just the hidden object part, you're out of luck anyway.

44929341.review:
Very cute and nice game with great atmospheric. If you like Anamita design games it's nearly the same. It's a shame I'm not heard from this game until it becomes free lately, I downloaded it and play it through in one go. The fact its a 2011 game and Colibri were not made another since then very sad.

The music was good, most of the puzzles were very good, but some (2-3) irritatingly challenging, and the "Help" button, not much of a help. And there were some (the arcade games) which were plainly annoying. But the rest was very good, It's a welcome bonus they did many new puzzles not just recycling every common one which you probably already know.

Also, I like the idea, you need to work for the Hints.

The playing time only 4-5 hours, if there weren't those 2-3 very hard puzzles, maybe even less (2-3 hours). The only problem is when you finished there's not an urge you go back and try again, no second playthrough, and If I saw in the demo there are puzzles not made it in the final game.

PS: If you like this one, try Alchemia, it has the same melancholic, sad atmosphere.

It's a cutesey hidden object adventure, casual, brief, time killer.  It's about 3 ish hours long. Recommended especially right now,as it's being offered for free or when it's on sale (As I did several months ago) after that offer expires.

One huge caveat though. There is a game killing bug - that has been solved by the excellent community NOT the devs (Which is not cool, reallydevs. tbh). If on the last real exploratory area you have the sound muted for any reason (The musics pretty decent, though) and attempt to enter the final area the game will hard crash every time. i had two virtually complete goes at it including an uninstall before finding that solution.

Replay value is limited, as it's really only the mini games from the final area that you can do again, without replaying the whole thing. It's doesn't vary so once solved it's kind of done. Despite that it's not a time spent I regret so I'd have to say. Yeah give it a try. It's pretty good.

The game is cute surrealistic game. It is very charming. I liked the art a lot.
The world was hit by meteor and it broke apart on a lot of puzzle pieces. You need to gather all pieces and gather it together. There are 5 small chapters. Each has 4 full size locations and a couple of small ones. Most of the time you need to seek objects on the map. Each level have 4 puzzles. They are different and simple, except 2-3.

In overall, the game is just awesome. I am not fun of Point & Click games, but this one is in my heart now. It is an awesome feature to know that your compatriots make such great games.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1520581718
Pros
- A nice mix of genres, hidden-object and puzzle game. I liked hidden-object part a lot 
- There are no character and dialogues, so you don't need to waste time for reading/waiting
- The world is so cute
- Soundtrack is charming
- Puzzle are diverse
- The game is short and could be passed in 3 hours.

Cons
- Some puzzles can you drive crazy. Especially, globe and compass puzzles.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1520581683
[h1]Resume[/h1]

44702223.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review [/h1]

The Tiny Bang Story is a game developed and published by Colibri Games

The Tiny Bang Story is a short hidden object game wrapped in a small-scale world consisting of a handful of beautifully hand-drawn areas

The game's art style is in the like of a children's book, also, the soundtrack offers rich, upbeat compositions that stand out but don't disrupt any intense eyeing or puzzling

The game also offers easy to medium style of difficulty games, made for children to enjoy playing the game whilst not being too easy

The one thing that felt amiss was the often abrupt completion of an area without warning. There's always one set of optional puzzle pieces to collect but after finishing the stage, however, there's no way to get back, apart from that, it's a cute and worthwhile game

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]
[list]
[*] None

44698644.review:
The Tiny Bang Story is a short hidden object game wrapped in a small-scale world consisting of a handful of hand-drawn areas. The found objects serve to activate a number of quick and small puzzle games which in turn unlock other objects to find or forward to the next area. 

As small as the world is presented, so rich in detail are the neatly drawn pictures. Its art style is in the like of a children's book with impossible constructions set in a fabled, munchkin sized environment. Correspondingly, the soundtrack offers rich, upbeat compositions that stand out but don't disrupt any intense eyeing or puzzling.

In light of the fact that this is a game appropriate for children, the puzzles are compact and reasonable, potentially too easy for more experienced puzzle people. The Tiny Bang Story draws on the immense pool of casual puzzles, incorporating sliding, pipe and jigsaw puzzles, among other classics of the genre.

The one thing that felt amiss was the often abrupt completion of an area without warning. There's always one set of optional puzzle pieces to collect but after finishing the stage, there's no way to get back. Apart from that, it's a cute and worthwhile game.

44445895.review:
The Tiny Bang Story is a small, but also a slightly challenging game, that takes you around the planet and requires you to fulfil tasks for the inhabitants there, to make them happy.

There are two sides of this game. More than one good, and one that is really bad.

The first thing you realise when playing this game is that you need patience. You need patience to find different items to progress,  patience to find the puzzle pieces and also finishing minigames.

First take the positive. The music is nice, the game is relaxing and it has nice graphics for a 2D game. However the game, no matter how pretty it is, can eventually turn boring, if you can't find the items you are looking for. That was the least of my problems in this game. They always ended up being found anyway.

My biggest problem was the minigames, and especially those with color. I am colorblind for bright green, and dark yellow, or something in between, so two of the puzzles in the game were almost impossible to finish without help from a friend. One game where I only saw 2 colors, there were actually 3 colors, and in another color puzzle I had put the yellows on the green, and the green on the yellows. You get the point. So this is pretty terrible for someone that got problems with color to solve on their own.

When you get bored in this game, it sucks, but otherwise a nice game, and I can recommend it.

-Not enough lore. The whole concept of the story is to gather puzzle pieces in order to retore your planet from the tiny bang, And that is pretty much it. The secenenry does tell a story, but it doesn't get in deppth. The only recurring character you see is the chubby guy as the game icon. Not much after.

-There are 2 puzzles that is similar to the action genre. Don't get hit while you are travling. The only two problems I have with those puzzles is that it requires you to use the mouse to click on the buttons while the game advacning every frame. It took me a while to complete those puzzles because I reacted to fast or that I couldn't get comfortable with the controls. 

-The game is too short. It took me apporximatley 2 hours to finish the game. I wish it lasted longer. Once you beat the game, you have access to the puzzles you beat before. 

Other than those flaws, I enjoyed my experience. But if you were to buy this game, wait for a sale. To be honest, the game isn't worth the full price of 5 bucks. Get it for around 1 dollar. It is worth the money if you saved it.

This game is phenomenal, but before I get into anything, I want to state with absolute clarity: If you are colourblind, you will have an extremely difficult time playing, and be unable to solve every puzzle by yourself. There is at least one puzzle/minigame I recall off the top of my head that requires precise identifying of varying hues of red, orange, yellow, green, and purple.

Okay, so. I went into this game having no idea what to expect. And holy cow, this is an amazing game. Be aware that it isn't very long (it's called The Tiny Bang Story, after all). Every moment you get out of the game is worth it.

It is easy in some areas, and incredibly difficult in others. I did look up some help guides for a couple of parts, and both of them I absolutely never would have gotten them. 

If you have $5 to spend, and you're looking for a different type of puzzle game, I highly recommend this game. It's cute, language-free, and an all-around blast. Be prepared to think outside the box.

41906702.review: I loved this game. The art was amazing and I thought the puzzles were cool. The way the story followed the little boy's life was interesting, and did I mention the art? :-) The jigsaw puzzles to put the world together was a nice touch, I thought, and I liked the way the world swayed just a little. I'm also easily entertained. The thing that's really nice about this game is that I felt it was appropriate for all ages, there's no talking, and it's all fairly self-explanatory. It's the sort of game I could see a kid and their parent or grandparent playing together as well as anyone who just enjoys good art. I don't often comment on music because I may listen to a little bit, but I have to keep an ear out for my kitten, and my older cat goes crazy if there are birds in the soundtrack, but what I heard of this one was nice. 41210169.review: Really enjoyed this hybrid game. It's a hidden-picture-puzzle game! Hidden picture games are neat, but they lack gameplay. Puzzle games are typically dreary. This is a steady stream of creative and careful searching, with out of the box puzzle solving, but it never gets too difficult to become discouraging. I wish - I really WISH - that other point and click adventure games that I've played could have such great gameplay. If this game had a written narriative, then it might be one of the best point and click adventure games that I have played. As it is, its just a great puzzle game. I think the key is that it is never so difficult that the gameplay comes to a stop, even while always feeling challenged. So, I would really enjoy getting more games like this one. It ran perfectly on ubuntu linux, and the animations were perfectly smooth, even on low-end hardware. Great sound and perfectly lovely graphics. Only complaint is the game length. [b]Deduction, logic, observation, luck... If you like puzzle games that require some thinking without, however, needing an engineer degree, this game is for you.[/b]

The Tiny Bang Story is a short (4-5 hours) yet stimulating game in which you have to find hidden objects and solve puzzles. There is no story at all, so don't expect a Point & Click adventure - or any BANG for that matter. Even if most of the puzzles are indeed accessible, some will require more time, patience and... a functional brain !

The gameplay is quite simple and intuitive ; navigate through the areas, collect items, unlock puzzles, find what's missing, solve puzzles, unlock more areas, etc. If at some point you don't know what to do and are out of ideas, there's a hint button to prevent despair. Let's not forget to mention the gorgeous and colourful hand-drawn artwork and the relaxing soundtrack that make the playing experience so much more enjoyable.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1324608217

I would recommend the Tiny Bang Story if you're looking for an average puzzle solving game to lighten up, take up the challenge, or just to kill time, because it's a cute and refreshing adventure.

36536396.review:
[b][u]Overall Rating: 8.5/10[/u][/b]

I really enjoyed this game, so far. (Not finished yet.) 
Very nice artwork, very clean, crisp and colorful. The cratoonish style suits it well.
It is not really a Hidden Object game (only User-defined tags say it is... the dev's official tags say Adventure, Casual, Indie. Which it is.)
Yes, you have to find pieces for completing projects and puzzles, but none are really hidden. Some are just harder to spot than others, lol! Maybe borderline HOPA, with more P (puzzles) than HO (hidden objects). Some puzzles are quite easy, some are more difficult to figure out. Some can be quite frustrating to figure out what you need to do, since there is no in game guide or tutorial to help you along. However, this makes you think, and also prevents bad language localizations/bad translations. 
Hints are easy to earn, by clicking the little mosquitos lying around until the hint bubble is filled. Some hints aren't as helpful as they could be though, and there is no penalty for using hint after hint. Kind of disappointed with that "feature", but it is a casual game, not a hardcore one. 

Runs beautifully on a toaster, even a very toasty toaster. Not hard on the CPU or GPU at all. No crashes or bugs found in over 5 hours of play so far, and I am not expecting to see any. 

Good time killer, that I found to be best played in short sessions (finish 1 puzzle or area, then take a break... for me, anyhow).The story is not clear, but for me, that was fine, as I enjoy imagining my own story as I play. The music was good, soothing, not overwhelming, nothing great, but nothing terrible. Good amount of things that made me chuckle or smile so far

I still feel it is worth the full asking price, but getting it at discount would be good, if you can. The price/hour is quite reasonable at full price.

Just my opinions on the game. Your Mileage May Vary. Widely. 

But I am looking forward to seeing what this little Indie Studio comes up with next.

34513699.review:
This is primarily a hidden object game with a variety of additional mini-games throughout, plus a puzzle you complete in between each of the game's chapters.

Pros:
+ It's cheap, and if you get it on sale the already low price is even nicer.

+ The game music is pretty and soothing.

+ Lovely hand-drawn artwork.

+ There's a somewhat helpful in-game hint system. Collect the little blue bugs and eventually you'll earn enough that you can use a little red bug to find whatever's on the screen that you've missed (or confirm that there's nothing there to find). You can also use the hint system to get what are often necessary hints as to what to do in the mini-games. In fact, sometimes you're given full solutions - but be aware that sometimes these "solutions" are actually lies.

Cons:
- Badly designed. It's quite possible to leave an area forever without collecting all of the area's puzzle pieces, and some areas somehow have too many. Granted, this didn't cause any problems later on (you'll always have enough puzzle pieces to build the World puzzle), but it still annoyed me.

- I loathed several of the mini-games, in particular the two fake arcade games and the water wheel puzzle. Unlike some reviewers, I did feel that the game provided enough information to figure out what to do with the various puzzles, but sometimes those puzzles were just plain annoying. With the water wheel puzzle, I got too frustrated trying to figure out the pipe paths, and the arcade games had terrible controls and were a chore to get through.

- It was a good thing that the World puzzle pieces stuck in place when they were in the correct spot, because the colors of several of them were off (mainly the all blue and white ones) and I'd never have figured out where they were supposed to go otherwise.

- Full-screen mode is glitchy and not truly full-screen with my screen resolution (1920 x 1080) - there were black bars around the image and everything was a little stretched. Display settings were very basic, so there was no way to even try to fix these issues. I ended up playing in windowed mode.

- I actually checked a walkthrough to make sure I'd really finished the game. The ending came very suddenly and looked like it might potentially be some kind of epilogue, but not so much. You could listen to any music track from the game and replay the mini-games and that was it. The mini-games didn't have good replay value, so it felt pretty pointless.

Overall, this was a disappointment. The atmosphere is great and the puzzle difficulty level is usually pretty good, but it has some appalling design issues and I hated the first arcade mini-game so much that I almost rage-quit when I came across the second one.

The Tiny Bang Story is fun little game. I have replayed it at least three times if not more and each time the game was surprisingly interesting, addicting and fun. From time to time I check if there are other games similiar to this one, but, sadly, no success.

Atmosphere is the main element that makes The Tiny Bang Story so compelling. It has simple mechanics, beautiful hand drawn graphics and light music.

This game is excellent choice if you want to just relax and have some fun, especially if you don't have too much time to immerse yourself in complex worlds and too tired to play games where success is highly dependent from your physical reflexes.

Narrative - there is some kind of a background story, which works for giving a context to the game. I never really understood it and it really never mattered to me.
Aesthetics - in my opinion, the strongest part of the game. Game is beautiful, emotional, the game world makes you wonder.
Game mechanics - simple point and click game, where you have to find hidden objects and solve some puzzles.

33316151.review: Just finished the Tiny Bang Story game and I can say it was very enjoyable.  I place a high value on the visuals of a game.  This one was outstanding in its artistic presentation.  If you enjoy finding hidden shapes inside a complex picture you will enjoy this game as well.  It also offers a chance to place puzzle pieces after every level of the game for those jigsaw puzzle fans.  Many puzzles were a bit reminiscent of a family favorite game from Microsoft called "Pandora's Box,"  although others were downright engineering in nature.  Overall, it took me just 7 hours to complete the game and I imagine a quicker study might do it in 4-5 hrs.  I bought this on sale, in a bundle, so it was well worth the $0.62 I paid.  I believe the artwork alone is well worth the regular retail price.  One comment for those beginning to play the game.  There are obvious shapes to collect that you will see right away, but you often need to complete the collection of an earlier shape before you can start to collect the others (complete the early quest first).  Completion of each quest often opens new rooms to explore which is where that last piece or two may be hiding.  So, I recommend looking forward before over-analyzing existing areas.

32748113.review:
Tiny Bang Story is a nice little puzzler with some issues.  I got it in a bundle on sale so for the price I actually paid, it was worth it.  I highly doubt I'll replay the game.  I recommend it at the price I paid if you absolutely love these little games.  Full price, I'm not sure.

It has the hidden objects as well as mini puzzles and when you fiinish the game you can just play the little puzzles.  There are hints that you can use for some of the hidden objects that require you to fill it up to use it.  The puzzles had a hint about what you need to do to solve it, not a hint that was helpful in solving the puzzle if you got stuck just a hint on the mechanics.  To some that's a problem others a bonus.

The issues I had were with the hidden object portion of the game.  
[olist]
    [*]You had to find puzzle pieces throughout and it gave you a number of how many to find.  It worked perfectly for the first chapter.  On the second I got stuck because it said I found all my puzzle pieces but I couldn't go forward.  Using the hint it came up with a puzzle piece that I'm almost positive I'd already gotten and I couldn't see anymore.  But apparently it was there.  For the last two chapters each time it said I was missing pieces but I continued on without a problem.  Even checking with guides showed that I had all the ones they had.
    [*]The other items you had to find were parts of little machines and puzzles you needed to do in order to progress.  You knew what they were because they were all over the place, but you couldn't collect them until you triiggered that little device.  So you end up running back and forth over the same three or four little areas collecting things over and over again.  That got a little old by the end.
[/olist]

Overall I'm pleased with this as it was bonus game for me.

32665565.review:
Tiny Bang Story is a cute little mouse-only point-and-click puzzle game with mechanics similar to Machinarium and other type games. It's pretty short, but it's got a pretty good spread of puzzles. Nothing you probably haven't seem before: lots of jigsaw puzzles, sliding piece puzzle to make a picture, move-all-the-pieces-to-the-correct-spot-with-only-one-free-space, some old-school arcade games like fly-your-ship-down-a-maze-and-don't-run-into-walls, and your generic hunt-for-10-components hidden object puzzles. But even when you immediately know what to do (i.e. all the Tetris-looking blocks need to fit into a rectangular space with no holes), actually doing them can take quite a bit of effort.

This game also does a couple of interesting things, though although these are all positives, they also become rather tedious after a while: 

1) the hint system. You have a bar to fill up to get a hint (normal), but you have to collect little flying insects to fill up the bar (interesting). However, it takes a LOT of them, and if you're stuck on two different items you're trying to find, expect to do a lot of clicking.
2) It's linear, but non-linear (if that makes sense). You definitely have a certain sequence to follow (e.g. find 10 of these things to unlock a puzzle, which gives you a key, which opens a door, which reveals another puzzle that needs 15 of this other thing to open, etc.) However, you can have multiple TYPES of things to search for at any given time, and for each of those TYPES, there are tons of actual ITEMS to find. However, since there is some linearity to it, you'll start to notice a ton of a given item but be unable to pick them up until you find the machine or door that requires all those items. This makes for a lot of "Now, where did I see that thing earlier?" hunting.

It's got cute art, and a neat (but simple) story of you trying to put back your tiny little world. Putting back the world is actually a puzzle in itself (a literal jigsaw puzzle), which is a nice little detail.

So, is this game groundbreaking? Hell no. Is it worth full price? Probably not. But is it worth the $1 I spent on it? I think so. Despite some minor annoyances, I got my dollar's worth.

28039205.review:
I never write reviews on games, so perhaps that speaks to this game because here I am.

After the first two hours, I really enjoyed this game. The art style is lovely and unique (many p&c games look as if they use the same assets, not here) and the music is relaxing. There doesn't seem to be much of a story, and the puzzles are standard fare - find so many of this object, slider puzzles, color matching, etc. If you get stumped, you can collect flies that periodically show up on screen to fill up your hint bubble, though hints will only work if you're on the correct screen where the object you're looking for resides. Clicking the hint bubble on a screen where there are no objects yields nothing, and no tooltip or anything to let you know to move along.

Where the game started go to sour for me was the arcade-style minigames. They are very slow, moving frame by frame every second. In one you move a boat through water, avoiding whales and mines. It took a few tries to get the hang of, but it wasn't too bad. Not exactly what I had in mind when I bought the game, and it felt like it went on a bit longer than necessary, but I could look past it. The second arcade-style minigame, though... I find quite frustrating. You move a plane left to right as it's flying down, avoiding the bad black planes as well as obstacles in the form of trees. This minigame is much more difficult, and is where I stopped playing. If you don't move at the exact right moment, or choose the wrong path, you crash and have to start over. I'm only in the third chapter of the game, so I don't know how many more minigames of this style are waiting for me, and I don't much care to find out. I had to take a break out of frustration, and wonder if the frustration is even worth continuing to play.

For this reason, I would not recommend this game. It has a lot more going for it than the few annoying arcade minigames, but those stand out quite a bit if they're not your cup of tea (as is the case for me). It's such a shame as the art style is so nice. This game may be worth checking out when it's significantly on sale, if you are at all curious about it.

27923921.review: I don't like hidden object games but this drew me in with it's hand-drawn artwork which is simply gorgeous. The hidden object aspect is well done but some objects can be frustratingly difficult to find because they blend in well with the environment and you overlook them. But it can feel rewarding when they are found so that's good. The puzzles are not too hard except a few maybe. And the soundtrack is absolutely excellent. I especially love the last track, "Time Stands Still" which feels very peaceful. I recommend playing the game with headphones. The game is short and can be completed in a couple of hours(depending on how quickly you solve the puzzles) but I would say, take your time and enjoy it. Very nice and relaxing game for a lazy Sunday afternoon.

27309536.review:
"The Tiny Bang Story" presents you with a small but fun world that you need to rebuild after a football (soccer ball) accidentally breaks apart.  This game contains several types of puzzles that you need to figure out in order to go through each level:  finding hidden object, matching patterns, discovering hidden areas,...  So if you like puzzle games, "The Tiny Bang Story" will be a lot of fun.

But there is more!  Each panel of hand-drawn art offers a beautiful background for all your puzzling fun.  The music is pleasant and happy (instead of annoying, cheesy, or elevator-like); the characters help you out; the big jigsaw puzzle fun to put together.  This game even has a built-in hint system.  Catch enough fireflies and the hint button in the upper right corner will fill up with blue, available to you in most areas of the game when you just need a small nudge to finish a challenge.

Overall, I love "The Tiny Bang Story" and I recommend it for all puzzle lovers.

26515742.review:
The best puzzle/hidden object game you can get for 1,24€ - I bought it on sale, just to make things clear - and this is coming from a person who utterly despises the hidden object concept.

Everything about this game oozes charm and uniqueness. The world is beautifully drawn, the music will help you relax after a long and difficult day, while the puzzles are not very difficult to solve. There are a few puzzles that might get you stuck, but there's no shame in checking the Internet for walkthroughs when it comes to this game. 

As for finding the hidden objects/puzzle pieces - as with every other game in the genre, some are instantly detectable, while others blend with the game background, so you will have to do the occasional click-all-over-the-screen thing. Even though I hate this element in games, The Tiny Bang Story is an exception - its atmosphere, music and style kept me going.

The hint system in this game is interesting - Other than showing you what you're supposed to do with the puzzles through illustrations, you can use it ONCE after you get enough mosquitoes and it will reveal the location of a puzzle piece you're supposed to collect. Then, it's getting mosquitoes all over again. 

Unfortunately, once you finish The Tiny Bang Story, there's no replay value whatsoever. Still, I thoroughly enjoyed the 4.7 hours I spent playing it and recommend it to every gamer out there.

But it's just a testament to how different peoples brains work and are wired, and I am grateful they did take the time to post their solutions because I'd never make it if they didn't. Apart from those couple of instances, it's a really pleasant game with cute music and art work.

25790355.review:
[u]GAMEPLAY[/u]
TBS is a delicate adventure that combines hidden object games with puzzle-solving. On starting each chapter you're shown a beautifully hand-drawn environment that usually requires finding a number of objects. As you click on these objects they are collected and stored. Before long you'll realise to progress, and see another funny/peculiar screen, you have to dig around. The goal of each chapter is usually to find an ultimate component that sets some sort of mechanism in motion. Puzzles and games were perfectly-pitched being neither too easy nor too hard and the well-designed environments always made the experience a fun an enjoyable one.There is a very good hint system - where you fill up the question mark meter by clicking on the buzzing flies - but I still had to resort to a couple of visits to YouTube. However, these occurrences were few and didn't ruin immersion. 

[u]PRESENTATION & DESIGN[/u]
TBS is not only a very well-presented production but an inventive one as well. The hand-drawn environments are like those beautiful picture books you stared at and found so intriguing when you were a child. Massive attention to detail has been made in the artwork department and the sound also suits the visual tone harmoniously. A delicate, melodic piece is heard as you play; subtle enough to be enjoyed but not intrusive enough to put you off. Sound effects are spot-on as well. The game consists of about five or six chapters that might take about an hour each to complete. At the end of each chapter you get to fill in daytime pieces of a globe that cleverly shows your progression. It's a good system as it divides the game into five or six parts and, like a book, allows you to take a break at convenient points. 

[u]CONCLUSION[/u]
There are text-heavy adventure games that require you to wade through mountains of dialogue and then there are breezier adventure games with the emphasis on actually playing a game! The Tiny Bang Story may not be for everyone as it will certainly make you stop to think and may even bring in mild frustration as you search maddeningly for that last elusive piece but, for me, I put it at one of my personal favourite adventure games.

4/5


For the full review of this and other games please check out or follow my curator page at:
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/26108770-Parsons%27-Garden/]Parsons' Garden[/url]

25760116.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/96000/]The Tiny Bang Story[/url] is a surprisingly charming one part puzzle adventure and one part hidden object game. It's a nice little title, unpretentious and pleasantly relaxing, but only if you can get it to run.[/h1]

Locating various recurring objects is required to access locked areas or repair machines. You can't collect these series until they're explicitly needed. Each chapter is reasonably sized so backtracking through scenes is simple enough. You can usually tell in advance when certain objects will be required eventually upon spotting their multiplicity.

Delightfully detailed backgrounds with a lovely surreal Eastern European vibe can be favorably compared to some of Amanita Design's excellent games, more specifically [url=steamcommunity.com/id/ElusiveOne/recommended/40700]Machinarium[/url].

Accessible UI keeps track of the items you've collected and how many more you need, with a reminder of where they'll be useful once you have a completed set. Acquire conventional puzzle pieces throughout each of the 5 chapters to put the world map back together. Most of them blend quite well with the environment.

Puzzles range from a variety of simple jigsaws to fine variations on common logic puzzles. You will put a lot of things back together. There's nothing truly revolutionary here but everything is well presented and only a few puzzles are really difficult. Hints are available on demand but they sometimes directly reveal the answer or are not helpful at all.

It turns out to be a very relaxing and pleasant experience, except for arcade sequences that feel out of place and defiantly ruin the mood with their needlessly poor controls. Thankfully they are short and few.

[h1]Beware some potentially serious technical hiccups.[/h1]

[i]Warning: Under no circumstance should you attempt to play the game in full screen mode.[/i] I initially gave this game a negative score because it constantly presented a blank screen and subsequent exit to desktop, without any way to fix it despite clean reinstalls.

The game did run fine on my secondary work laptop, but I never attempted the full screen option for fear of locking myself out of a potentially good game. You too may be forced to play on a tiny window since the game runs in a very low resolution on today's HD monitors.

25653932.review:
A nice, if unspectacular point and click, hidden object game. Throughout five chapters, each made up of about four screens filled with things to interact with, you'll click on various people or mechanisms to initiate quests to find some hidden items they require. Once found and brought back, it will typically trigger a mini puzzle of some kind and give you another item upon completion that'll help you progress further. That's basically the long and short of it.

There is some kind of story about a meteor hitting "Tiny Planet" and scattering the world apart in the form of jigsaw pieces which are hidden all over the place, but it's largely inconsequential and serves only to back up a puzzle mechanic and explain how you access each chapter in turn (even though the jigsaw pieces aren't actually necessary to move on). There also seems to be a recurring character that appears in paintings and photographs showing him at different stages as he grows up, but the significance of this is never explained. Presumably we're retracing his steps in places that either he had an impact on, or which had an impact on him. It's hard to tell, and to be perfectly honest, even harder to care, since this is never expanded upon in any meaningful way or as any clear goal for the player.

Most of the puzzles and hidden objects are pretty fun and fair deals, but occasionally there's the odd obscure one that will have you either losing all faith in humanity, or else looking up a guide. I'm also really not a fan of them messing with the scale of the hidden objects, like having large jigsaw pieces in one place, then other, much small ones in other places yet still at the same distance away from the camera perspective. More consistancy of scale with the objects would be appreciated.

You'll have a fun, if not somewhat forgettable, two or so hours with the game, and have the option to replay any puzzle when you reach the end... which is possibly the most anti-climactic end I've ever experienced in a game. But I'd still recommend it for anyone looking for a quick break through a visually pretty world with some fun and engaging puzzles.

23307691.review:
Absolute gem of a game.
Yes, the fact it's a HOG (hidden object game) might turn people off, and that's a shame, because The Tiny Bang Story is an amazing little adventure into a unique world with an art style reminiscent of "Machinarium" or "Botanicula", a sound track rivaling 2D Boy's "World of Goo" and "Little Inferno", and has top notch puzzle gameplay.
In some ways, it's similar to "Morphopolis", in that it throws you straight into the game without instructions, and you have to find your way around with little to no help, adding a huge amount of immersion.
It's cheap, worth paying full price, although it shows up on discount occasionally, and it's well worth the 3-4 hours it will take to beat it. Longer if new to the genre.

The only negative is the issue regarding a few of the art assets in the game, which may have been borrowed and then altered to suit the style of the game, but there is a fine line between copying and inspired by.

Regardless, The Tiny Bang Story is a breath of fresh air, relaxing, unique, and worth your time. If you do decide to try it and enjoy it, I also recommend all the games I've mentioned above, as they are equally as good and enjoyable.

22513663.review:
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The Tiny Bang Story is a point-and-click adventure game, where a meteor blow up the world. It is up to you to put back the puzzle pieces and save the world. All story is the explained by the intro and is never mentioned again. You go through all the chapters and do small puzzles and mini games. There's multiple location in one chapter and you have to complete all the puzzles in the first location before it pans to the next one. All the puzzle in this game is fairly easy, but some quite tedious. For example: Before you can start a new chapter, you have to solve a puzzle piece. It is quite lazy and boring game design. It should not hold you back of an excellent indie game. 

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
All graphics in this game is drawn by hand and it is phenomenal beautiful with its light, charming colors and cute art style. It takes everyday objects and scale them big. I am quite amazed how well done and creative the art really is.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Definitely one of my favorite soundtracks ever done. Relaxing music, which suits the whole art style of the game. I can still hear all the soundtracks playing in my head. It is that good! Fantastic music for an indie game, no one has really heard about.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
This is probably my most played point-and-click game. It is really short, but the soundtrack, art style and puzzles are enough go back. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves these types of games.

What I imagine the devs talked about before this game:

- Hey, let's make the most boring game ever. Like gnaw off your leg boring
- How 'bout a HOG, but instead of a story and puzzles, the player will just collect a bunch of items from the world. Like 8 gears for one machine and stuff.
- Will we include the hint button? Yes, but we'll make it useless. If it's supposed to point into a puzzle location, it will not work. Also, it will not recharge with time, we'll make the player hunt little bugs floating around the screen.
- Oh, and we'll make the world a jigsaw puzzle, but only a tiny part of it will be open. So in every level, the player has to find a bunch of jigsaw pieces and then assemble them to open the next part. And at least half of the pieces will be the sky, with no fucking difference between them.
- Why don't we add a click counter that sends clicking stats back to us, so we can have a laugh at how the poor players click around?

I couldn't verify the last part, but nonetheless: there's nothing here that's remotely fun or interesting or engaging. The only word that comes to mind in connection with this game is AVOID.

Try [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/40700/]Machinarium[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/207690/]Botanicula[/url], or [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/3260/]Safecracker: The Ultimate Puzzle Adventure[/url] instead, which I actually enjoyed.

19735466.review:
To summarise my major emotion about TTBS: it's frustrating.

The game has a sharp, yet storybook-like art style, catchy (though quickly monotonous) music, and a hidden object/puzzle/adventure gameplay. I love all of these features, then what went wrong?

The game basically doesn't contain any written or spoken text, and any hints it gives about objectives or solutions are extremely sparse and unhelpful. Thus a significant portion of my playtime was spent wandering around the same handful of screens, trying to figure out [i]what the game wants me to do[/i].

Once you [i]do[/i] figure it out, the rest of the time is spent either hunting minute objects that you've passed many times before, but only become collectable when the game decides to do so, or doing one of the quite difficult puzzles (without a skip function and barely a single hint! annoying!) or one of the timed minigames (which really don't fit to the otherwise quite laidback gameplay).

To acquire any kind of help from the game, you have to collect 30 little floating bugs for each use of the hint button, and even then it only showed a hint to me on puzzle screens, not when I spent ages looking for the last few tiny objects in the general game screens.

Despite the art style being pleasant, the game seems to have quite a confusion on what visual theme it wants to pursue - the end result is a haphazard mix of fairytale, steampunk-ish and retro-futuristic elements.

Another noticeable thing for me was the lack of "player character". There's no body through which a player acts, feeling like I was some invisible disembodied force which still needed lifts and ladders to get to various places, resulting in the weird, empty feeling of both being there and not being there. It was probably one of the reasons why I didn't connect emotionally with the game at all - it felt like a soulless exercise of cookie-cutter charm.

Through my playtime the game felt more and more like a chore that I just wanted to be over and done with - then I remembered that games are supposed to be fun, and just dropped it altogether. A disappointment!

PS: I recommend to either use a walkthrough, or go play a game with actual charm, character and way less frustrating gameplay, like Botanicula or Samorost.

This one is like mid way between adventures like Samorost or Machinarium and a HOG. 18827200.review:
In theory, "The Tiny Bang Story" is a Hidden Object Game (HOG).  In reality, it's not.  Yes.  There are teeny tiny little objects to be found throughout the game.  But, that's not what a HOG is.  It's not really that important since other things swamp my rating.  But, it's something to be aware of.  The big thing that hurts the game is that nothing (absolutely nothing) is explained.  We're dumped into a setting with no idea what we're supposed to do, how to do it, or why.  The next biggest issues is somewhat related:  once we figure out what we're doing, we get into mini-puzzles.  But, once again, we're given no idea what to do with them.  Most of them can be figured out with the hint they give us.  But, some of them remain entirely opaque (I finished several by blindly flailing around with the mouse and never understood what I'd done to "succeed").  Next, as we move around the screen looking for those hidden objects or the secret areas they might be in, the cursor doesn't change to indicate any "hot" zones.  Basically, the game turns into a click-fest because we have to click on every single thing we see in case it's important.  And finally, the puzzles and objects aren't necessarily "necessary" to the game.  In the second area, I skipped a puzzle so I could come back to it later.  I ended up brute-forcing another puzzle which, I think, the puzzle I skipped was supposed to open.  The game happily let me do this and leave the area without ever finishing that puzzle.  In the third area, I finished the last puzzle before gathering the last hidden puzzle piece.  When I placed the object from that last puzzle where it belonged, the game happily moved me from the area and gave me all the puzzle pieces I needed for the world-puzzle.

I got 4.0 hours of game-play out of this.  So, the list price is a bit high purely from a dollar-per-hour aspect.  But, even if the game were much cheaper (heck, I paid 50 cents for it), the issues I noted above just put the game into the Not-Recommended area.

18356884.review:
Hidden object games have never been my thing, but after playing through this exquisite little gem, I may have to branch out a little. From the music to the charming little puzzles interspersed throughout, you'll find much more than a time waster on your hands. 

With no conventional story to be had, the whole plot basically revolves around collecting the puzzle pieces that make up the world. You'll encounter an individual character in each area, and you'll see a broad narrative of a young boy's adventures as you go, but it's mainly background. Everything in this game is hidden in plain site, but a keen eye can spot the majority of the items often before you even need to pick them up. This is all bundled in an absolutely gorgeous art style that makes use of pastels to give an authentic painting look. Every puzzle has its own twist, and there was only one puzzle out of the dozens I encountered that seemed to not follow any discernable logic. Some of the puzzles you encounter are often more mini-games than anything, from a simon-says challenge to some challenges that look like they came straight from a Commodore 64. Variety isn't something I was expecting with this, but by god is there a lot.

The only hiccups in design is that once you leave an area, you can't return. Not that I found anyway. The early areas indicate the ending through obvious cues, but some of the last areas aren't as obvious, and it led to me leaving behind a few as yet unfound puzzle pieces (I think 3 in all). Curiously, I was still able to put the world back together without a single piece left out so it's not a big deal, but my OCD aches that I couldn't get the other pieces. That, and the hint system is nearly worthless, and kind of a pain in the butt to charge. You have to collect dozens of bugs for one use, and no matter if it's charged or not they still litter the screen. You won't need the hint system generally though, so it's all minor gripes, but a desire to turn off the bug hints was rather high for me.

There are few games that can put me at piece as easily as this one did, and it served as a wonderful sleepaid after work and the like. For something a little different that harkens back to the Pajama Sam days but with a sense of grace to it, it's really a genuinely pleasant experience, and that is hard to come by these days. Absolutely worth it.

A gorgeous and somewhat challenging hidden-object game, with several nice puzzles and a few simple mini-games.

Well, I recommend it, but keep your expectations low. There is no story and no point-and-click adventuring: your only task is to find all the objects, and they are quite hard to find indeed! Supposedly you need to collect all the puzzle pieces, but I did not and still completed the game.

If you've enjoyed the audio-visual style here, I strongly recommend Amanita Design's games--Machinarium, Botanicula--which offer wonderful stories and much more gameplay.

If you've enjoyed the gameplay here, well, "hidden-object games" is a huge genre. There are many excellent "HOGs" on Steam. Welcome aboard!

Finally, I'd like to thank the developer for supporting Linux.

16570949.review:
Tiny Bang Story is primarily a hidden object game. The good things it has going for it are that the soundtrack is good, the hidden object gameplay is relaxing and satisfying, and the art is absolutely amazing. The art is very reminiscent of Amanita Design (e.g. Samarost, Machinarium).

One important thing to note about Tiny Bang Story that will make it or break it for you, though, is that the hidden object gameplay is periodically broken up by actual puzzles you have to solve or mini-arcade games where you have to navigate a pixel boat or airplane through some pixel trees and rocks, etc. These little puzzles and mini-games add more flavor and variety to the game, so on one hand they are welcome. On the other hand, the little atari-style mini games are not very fun, and they go on for what seems like an excessively long time, and if you make one mistake, you have to start the whole tedious thing over again. The puzzles are usually of the jigsaw or tangram variety, but there are some permutation or mathematical puzzles in there as well. At first these are very light and easy, but by the time you make it to the third or fourth area of the world, they suddenly become way more demanding and can be very cumbersome (I especially disliked the puzzle where you have to balance the luggage on the scales and the astrolabe puzzle is just objectively terribly designed). This is especially true if you are primarily interested in the hidden object gameplay. You may find yourself wanting to just look up the solution so you can get back to searching for hidden objects and avoid being obstructed by these.

The game also has a hint system, which you can activate by swatting a bunch of flies until you fill up a hint meter, but in my experience, there were 2 or 3 situations where I pressed the hint button and it either did not give any hint at all (literally did nothing) or it gave me an absolutely useless hint, essentially telling me what my objective is or some other such information I already know.

Overall it seems like a pretty good game. I enjoyed the art and music, and I enjoyed how relaxing and warm it is. I personally felt the puzzles and mini-games got to be too cumbersome after a certain point, so I've lost my interest in finishing it, but it will be a very good game for the right kind of person.

16542074.review:
Positives :
1- Its very cute and charming
2- The music is relaxing
3- Puzzles can be interesting in a passtime way

Negatives
1- Too many hidden object goals, with some being utterly camouflaged and/or incredibly tiny. These are required.
2- Jigsaw puzzles are long, annoying and frustating. On top of it, the music decided to stop so I quit.
3- The hint system is dumb - you have to click flies over and over and over and over... why? just... why?
4- Complete lack of story. 
5- Perfect for an iPad ; for the kids to have a clickfest and look for the things together while in the car. On PC though, it just doesn't work - besides theres much more fun things to play.

Play Machinarium instead. This isn't even worth the dollar, even less your precious time, UNLESS you have kids that love silly puzzles.
